"This fast-thinking game challenges players to decipher everyday words and phrases using clues from creative SYMBOL SIMON(TM) picture puzzles. It's a fun challenging game for two or more players or for teams!"

,2000,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10657,Fleet Admiral,['Hexagon Grid'],"['Nautical', 'Wargame', 'World War I']","Fleet Admiral is a tactical naval game simulating the battles that were fought in WWI and that era. It includes portions of German, Russian, British, French, Turkish, Austro-Hungarian, Japanese, Spanish, Dutch, Italian, and US navies.

The system is similar to Tsushima published in Strategy & Tactics magazine (#130) although Fleet Admiral predates Tsushima. It includes 22 sheets of ship logs and 15 scenarios. The logs include ships not in the scenarios.

Fleet Admiral is an early example of DTP. Only 135 copies were made. It was laser printed with cardstock countersheets.

",1987,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10658,Ali Baba,"['Rock-Paper-Scissors', 'Roll / Spin and Move']","['Arabian', ""Children's Game"", 'Dice']","An obvious precursor to Alex Randolph's later Ciao Ciao, this game sees players moving figures back and forth over a bridge. Each player has 3 wood figures in different sizes, an officer, a lady and a robber, and there's a special die numbered 0-3. Roll the die, move a figure forward, and if it meets another on the bridge, the robber holds up the lady, the lady slaps the officer and the officer nabs the robber, sending them back to the start. Figures can only make the other side with an exact roll.

",1974,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10659,Hex Hex,"['Hand Management', 'Real-Time']","['Card Game', 'Fantasy', 'Humor', 'Real-time']","This is a card game that forces a Hex token around the table between players. In this respect, it's sort of a game of Hot Potato. Whoever can't get rid of the Hex token by using his cards "blows up," thus losing points. Naturally, there are nuances to this. There are 17 different cards in the deck, some which merely pass the Hex token left, right, and across, while others split the token in two, or increase it's damage. One dismisses it entirely. One blows it up while in another player's possession. One forces the token to pass in only one direction, some cause extra effects if the token DOES blow up on you. A round ends when there are no more Hex tokens available, and there are as many rounds as there are players, plus one.

There are some interesting strategies that are not immediately apparent, but which become obvious after the first couple of rounds. Controlling when the last token blows up is very important since you lose and gain points based on this, so learning to play the cards to force the location of the tokens when they blow up is of paramount importance. Sending them to a player who has no cards to play works very well for this.

Scores are kept with individual cards monitoring "Voice", which is just points. How many you have at the end of the x+1 rounds determines who the winner is.

One last amusing thing about the game is a bit of chaos tossed in; a Hex Hex card; when it's played, all players have to drop their card hands and put their hands in the air. The slowpoke loses points. Not exactly strategy, but still entertaining.

Integrates with:

Hex Hex Next


Reimplemented by:

Hex Hex XL


",2003,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10660,micropul,"['Hand Management', 'Modular Board', 'Pattern Building', 'Solo / Solitaire Game', 'Tile Placement']","['Abstract Strategy', 'Print & Play']","micropul is a strategic & tactical tile-laying game in which players are scientists trying to extract precious micropul matter from an energy core.

The game can be played as a solitaire puzzle or competitively.

Each player has a hand of tiles they must play optimally to keep a flow of new tiles coming in and if possible keep aside some tiles in a supply stack that will be worth more points at the end of the game. Drawing new tiles is done by activating catalysts, this part is very tactical.

During the game, groups of micropul of the same color will get formed. These groups can be claimed and will be worth a lot of points if they are closed at the end of the game. This is the strategic part.

Winning is done by balancing the tactical and strategic part.

Print & Play


http://neutralbox.com/micropul/
(Rules are available in English, Japanese, Spanish, Polish and French.)


Online Play


Boardspace.net (real time, robot option)
http://superpowernosissies.com/games/game-preserve/micropul/ (solitaire)


Mobile Apps

Boardspace.net local multiplayer or online, IOS
Boardspace.net local multiplayer or online, Android


",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10662,Victoria Cross: The Battle of Rorke's Drift,"['Area Movement', 'Dice Rolling', 'Movement Points', 'Secret Unit Deployment', 'Simulation']","['Post-Napoleonic', 'Wargame']","VICTORIA CROSS is a block style, area movement game covering the Battle of Rorke's Drift during the Anglo-Zulu war of 1879. The game plays in 2 hours and has 60 blocks, a full color mapboard with a 3d view of the battlefield, charts and dice. The game is very exciting and has many decisions to be made. Playable by the novice gamer and detailed enough for the grognard.

",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10663,The Civil War,"['Area Movement', 'Dice Rolling', 'Events', 'Simulation']","['American Civil War', 'Miniatures', 'Post-Napoleonic', 'Wargame']",""The Civil War", is a strategic simulation of this epic struggle of the war between the States. It is simple enough to appeal to the novice gamer and experienced gamers will discover that the game is very challenging and demanding. There are no difficult or tricky rules to read and master. The average player should have no difficulty in understanding the mechanics of the game in about 15 minutes.

",1992,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10664,Star Wars Miniatures Battles Companion,"['Dice Rolling', 'Point to Point Movement']","['Expansion for Base-game', 'Miniatures', 'Movies / TV / Radio theme', 'Science Fiction', 'Wargame']","A supplement for use with Star Wars Miniatures Battles. Add vehicle combat to your Star Wars Miniatures Battles game. This supplement contains full rules for vehicle combat, flight, a rules upgrade and expansion, new equipment and a miniatures battles campaign. Also included are details of unit insignia and organization for Rebel, Imperial and other forces in the galaxy.

Star Wars Miniatures Battles


",1994,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10665,Sequenz,['Pattern Building'],['Abstract Strategy'],"A game where one mustn' lose sight of one's opponent...

Each player gets 8 pieces. Players start placing their pieces on the gameboard which is divided in 7x7 squares. Each square contains one of 7 colors, letters and numbers (which each number, letter and color is exactly 7 times on the board).
After placing all pieces on the board players alternately move one of their pieces one square in any direction.

Whoever manages to place his pieces on 7 equal colors, numbers or letters wins (which IMHO is almost impossible when two equal opponents are playing...).

",1981,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10666,R.OC,"['Dice Rolling', 'Events', 'Point to Point Movement', 'Simulation', 'Variable Set-up']","['Economic', 'Medieval', 'Negotiation', 'Political', 'Religious', 'Territory Building', 'Wargame']",""R.OC" is a lavish (and expensive) wargame simulation of the power struggle between the four great feudal families of the thirteenth century Languedoc region of France.

Political, dynastic, economic and military aspects of the conflict are covered and the growth of the Cathar heresy and its suppression by the Inquisition play their historical parts. If a faction has acquired sufficient power, represented by the number of its feudal holdings, it can ‘do homage’ to the relevant sovereign and call on either the royal army of France or of Catalonia to intervene. In fact to achieve victory it must achieve this eminence as well as capture an enemy capital.

In a four-player game it is possible, suitable candidates being available, for a faction to ally with another by marriage and aim for a joint victory, unless Death do them part, albeit with more onerous conditions. The rules are modified slightly for two- and three-player games.

Caveat: This is a French-language production and there is some text on the event cards.

",2003,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10667,Hybrid: Expansion 1 – Nemesis,"['Dice Rolling', 'Modular Board', 'Variable Phase Order', 'Variable Player Powers']","['Expansion for Base-game', 'Fantasy', 'Fighting', 'Horror', 'Miniatures']","The Templars of the Griffin Empire have discovered a secret complex beneath on of the laboratories of the Hybrid Projest. A new enemy awaits them there, lurking in the darkness and ready to attack. The hunters of the Lodge of Hod have become its prey!

This box includes campaign rules, two short stories and two campaigns made up of three scenarios each, 3 metal miniatures, 55 new cards, numerous corridors, brand new game tiles and counters, as well as exclusive profiles for use in the Rackham range of games.

",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10668,Panzer Grenadier: Desert Rats,['Hexagon Grid'],"['Wargame', 'World War II']","Desert Rats is the seventh complete game from the Panzer Grenadier Series and picks up where Afrika Korps left off. Most of the scenarios are between November 1941 and May 1942 in North Africa but there are also some bonus scenarios that cover East Africa/Somali.

Two 22" X 34" maps, 825 counters. Two players but can be played very well solitaire. With Initiative determination phase and the action segment alternating between players, there is no sitting around waiting for your turn.

Nationalities include; British, German, Indian, Italian, Italian Colonial & New Zealand troops.

This game is part of the Panzer Grenadier series

Expanded by:

Panzer Grenadier: Sinister Forces


",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

column5: Walk along the road with other Bavarians and try to be the first to complete ten goals. The other players will surely try to stop you as soon as they can...

column1:
10672,"Easy Come, Easy Go","['Dice Rolling', 'Push Your Luck', 'Re-rolling and Locking']","[""Children's Game"", 'Dice']","Easy Come, Easy Go features gameplay familiar to anyone who's played Yahtzee or many other dice games, with you trying to roll combinations of dice in order to score. The nine combinations are four of a kind, two pairs, a straight, exactly 7, exactly 13, sum of 3 or less, sum of 17 or more, and three of a kind with all numbers being odd/even.

The four dice show numbers 0-5, and on a turn you roll all four dice, freeze one or more of the dice, roll all unfrozen dice, freeze one or more dice, etc. until either all four dice are frozen or you have achieved a combination and can claim the tile showing this combination, whether from the center of the table or from another player.

If you claim a third combination tile, then the next two players (or the same player twice in a two-player game) each have one chance to steal one of your combinations. If they fail to do so, you win! If they do steal one, then perhaps they now have three and have a shot at winning themselves!

",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10673,Monopoly: America Special Edition,"['Auction/Bidding', 'Player Elimination', 'Roll / Spin and Move', 'Set Collection', 'Trading']","['Economic', 'Negotiation']","Life, liberty, and the pursuit of properties. There's nothing more American than the game of Monopoly, except maybe a special America Edition of the world's most popular board game. You can own pieces of American culture and history, learn about American people and places, and move around the board using tokens that are as American as apple pie. Enjoy classic play or experience a new variation with our Corner Squares Game. Answer American challenge questions and you may get a property for free! This is an American Road Trip you don't want to miss.

The components for this consists of the following:

1-Gameboard
28-American History Deed Cards
Monopoly Money and Banker's tray
6-American themed movers
16-American People Cards
16-American Places Cards
90-American Challenge Cards
32-plastic houses
12-plastic hotels
2-DICE
4-Alternate Corner Squares
1-Set of Instructions.


",2002,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10674,Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot: ORANGE Booster,"['Dice Rolling', 'Hand Management', 'Take That', 'Trading']","['Card Game', 'Expansion for Base-game', 'Humor', 'Negotiation']","Killer Bunnies are back yet again featuring even zanier Specialty bunnies and introducing the Pawns (which will reveal the secrets of the P-Cards)! The Orange Booster Deck adds 55 cards to your existing set, plus six multi-colored Pawns.

Other fantastic cards include: Weil's Pawn Shop to give players a chance to buy back bunnies from a third Killer Bunnies market, Double Free Agents to make Bunny Triplets even easier, Selective Disclosure to reveal your opponents' cards before they're played, and Uriel's Machine to counteract any undesired Very Special card!

Can you reap the benefits of a Super Supplies Surprise? Aggravate your opponents with a forced "Do-Over" turn with Bunny On The Edge Of Forever! The Orange Booster Deck delivers increasing scopes of strategy and more twisted ways to win!

CONTENTS :: 55 large cards, 6 colored Pawns & Instructions

Expands:

Killer Bunnies and the Quest for the Magic Carrot


",2003,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10675,Das Schloss,"['Dice Rolling', 'Open Drafting', 'Role Playing', 'Tile Placement']","['Adventure', 'Dice', 'Exploration', 'Fantasy', 'Horror']",From the gamefest.com website game description: "Four daring adventurers enter the old castle...To meet the ghosts of not so daring long time gone adventurers. And to find some secret treasures and magic scrolls. Will they escape? An always new adventure game with beautiful wooden game pieces."

10676,Star Frontiers: Knight Hawks,"['Cooperative Game', 'Dice Rolling', 'Grid Movement', 'Hexagon Grid', 'Movement Points', 'Pick-up and Deliver', 'Point to Point Movement', 'Role Playing', 'Trading', 'Variable Player Powers']","['Science Fiction', 'Space Exploration', 'Wargame']",This board game of starship combat was published as part of the Knight Hawks supplement for TSR's Star Frontiers role playing game. ,1983,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10677,Iron Chef Board Game: The Ultimate Cooking Challenge,"['Roll / Spin and Move', 'Set Collection']",['Movies / TV / Radio theme'],"(From the back of the box)
Welcome to Kitchen Stadium!
Get ready for codfish and tomatoes to start flying as The Iron Chef: Ultimate Cooking Challenge comes to your home. Based on the hit TV show, Iron Chef, this frantic board game pits four culinary challengers against each other in a race to build the perfect meal!
Do you prefer Chinese? French? Italian? Or how about Japanese? It all begins when the surprise ingredient is revealed. Spin the wheel and race about the board in an attempt to assemble a complete meal - appetizer, main course, and dessert!
The real Iron Chefs chop, dice, and mince - you need to collect, trade, and discard cards to beat your opponents. But pitfalls abound! Watch out for dull knives, burnt vegetables, and stoves that don't work. Complete your meal, enter the inner circle of Kitchen Stadium and await the Judge's decision! Defend your title! Will you be King of the Iron Chef? Allez Cuisine!

",2003,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10679,A Fearful Slaughter: The Battle of Shiloh,"['Dice Rolling', 'Hexagon Grid', 'Simulation']","['American Civil War', 'Wargame']","This is it. As its sister game (This Hallowed Ground) did for Gettysburg and (This Terrible Sound) did for Chickamauga, A Fearful Slaughter strives to be the definitive Shiloh game.

Unrivaled in size, scope, accuracy, and development, A Fearful Slaughter is a game on the battle to be savored and played repeatedly. It uses the popular Civil War Brigade Series rules with a set of specially adapted extension rules for Regimental scale action.

The research for the two maps was done using multiple Park histories, battlefield surveys and county historical maps. They show the battlefield in more detail than ever before. They are very graphic intensive.

Multiple scenarios in an assortment of sizes make A Fearful Slaughter perfect for anyone who enjoys ACW gaming.
Unit Scale: Regiments & Batteries
Hex Scale: 100 Yards
Players: 2 (also suitable for solitaire play)
Playing Time: Varies with scenario played
Complexity: Moderate
Solitaire Suitability: High

(from MMP website)

",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10680,Jungle Speed Dodatek,['Pattern Recognition'],"['Action / Dexterity', 'Card Game', 'Expansion for Base-game', 'Party Game']",Jungle Speed Extension: Contains 80 new cards some of them with new special rules.

Some of the new cards allow players to stack their hands on top of the Totem without allowing it to fall or play with the cards of the player on their left!

,2003,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10681,Apples to Apples Junior,"['Hand Management', 'Simultaneous Action Selection']","['Card Game', ""Children's Game"", 'Humor', 'Party Game', 'Word Game']","As its name implies, this is a version of Apples to Apples designed for kids, although the basic game still works well with adults, too. The version has card optimized for middle-school aged children (9+). Also good for advanced grade-school aged children.

Compared to the original game, this edition features simplified words that even young children can understand and has no "suggestive" words that adults would be uncomfortable explaining to the kids.

Out of the Box changed the name of this game in 2007 from Apples to Apples Junior 9+ to Apples to Apples Junior. The Junior 9+ edition was originally sold in a small (288-card) box. It was changed to a bigger (576-card) box when the name was changed to Junior.

Note: Apples to Apples Kids was formerly called Apples to Apples Junior!, but was changed to Apples to Apples Kids when Apples to Apples Junior 9+ was changed to Apples to Apples Junior.

Part of the Apples to Apples Series.

",2002,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10682,Atlas & Zeus,"['Action Queue', 'Area Majority / Influence', 'Hand Management', 'Simultaneous Action Selection']",['Mythology'],"From www.thecompleatstrategist.com
Atlantis… As Plato first attested to in Critias, Atlantis was entrusted to the Titan Atlas by the gods, long before the dawn of history. His sons created there a magnificent civilization, a civilization that, among other things, succeeded in developing a potent magic that allowed them to transform into marine animals.

But the golden age would not last. When Atlas disappeared, his sons divided themselves into two clans and battled each other for the ultimate prize: sole rule over the kingdom of Atlantis and all of its riches.

Zeus, the ruler of all gods, decided to intervene and punish the greedy clans. He sent them a mighty flood that, in the span of one day and one night, engulfed the entire archipelago! Zeus told the Atlas' sons that he would save only the clan that succeeded in escaping the raging elements for the longest possible time.

Atlas & Zeus allows you to relive the final moments of Atlantis, the epic struggle of Atlas' sons for survival and Zeus' pardon. Which of the two of you will succeed in becoming the last of the Atlantians?

CONTENTS: 16 Island Tiles 16 Character Tiles 2 Decks of 25 Cards 1 Action Order Track 8 Game Markers 1 Rule Book

Part of the Eurogames Games for 2 Series.

",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10683,SEEKRIEG 5,"['Action Points', 'Dice Rolling', 'Measurement Movement', 'Simulation']","['Miniatures', 'Nautical', 'Wargame', 'World War I', 'World War II']","MINIATURES RULES FOR NAVAL COMBAT DURING THE AGE OF THE BATTLESHIP

SEEKRIEG 5 covers the entire 1880-1945 era in a single volume. SEEKRIEG 5 is naval warfare in the age of the battleship including surface warships, air operations, merchant vessels, and submarines.
Contents:
118-page rulebook and 100 pages of data tables covering weather, torpedo, radar and aircraft data covering the entire 1880-1945 era. (Foreword by Bill Jurens and Nathan Okun)

40 pages of game charts printed on heavy stock

30-page Damage Effects book

A sheet of color game markers.

A sheet of movement and turn rulers.

CD-ROMS containing the following ship logs and other game aids in Adobe Acrobat PDF format:

15 different historical and hypothetical scenarios covering from Yalu (1894) to Komandorski Islands (1943) and containing Order of Battle sheets, maps and over 250 individual Ship Logs.

Over 600 different Ship Logs for merchant vessels

Air Operations Log forms for air and carrier operations

Flag Command Log forms for 26 different countries

Movement rulers, markers and other game aids

SEEKRIEG 5 comes shrink-wrapped (un-boxed). All components are loose-leaf and 3-hole punched for storage in a standard ring binder.

",2004,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10685,Blick,[],"['Action / Dexterity', ""Children's Game""]",This game consists of a hand held plastic tray with a convex base with a small divot in the middle and a little plastic jumping bean (Mr. Blick) that is hollow with a small weight inside that moves to the bottom of the bean as it flips over producing an erratic motion. The object of the game is to get Mr. Blick to stand up in the divot in the middle of the tray by tilting the tray so that Mr. Blick flips end-over-end. The winner is the person who can do this in the shortest amount of time. Box says ages 3 and up.

,1993,,,;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

10686,Star Munchkin 1+2,"['Dice Rolling', 'Trading', 'Variable Player Powers']","['Card Game', 'Expansion for Base-game', 'Fighting', 'Humor', 'Science Fiction']",";;;;
;;;;
;;;;;"Publisher's DescriptionThe Munchkins take to the stars -- again!

Star Munchkin 2 brings the epic saga of The Clown Wars to life
column2: except with better acting... Star Munchkin took the rules-bending
column4: dungeon-crawling insanity of the original Munchkin and put the whole thing in space

there's still piles of treasure.

column217:
Rummage - A Game Straight Out Of The Top Drawer!

This game takes place in your own house. The board has several rooms which players mark on their score sheets as actual rooms in the place where you are playing
column218: so the Red room might be your kitchen
column219: the Green room might be your bathroom. Players then roll & move around the board and on entering a room another player draws question cards and letter cards from the relevant decks. So you might be asked "To name something you might see in the sky..." with the letter B. The player keeps answering questions and collecting letter cards if they give proper answers. If they fail
column221: their turn ends. You keep no more than 5 letters
column222: so if you get a 6th letter
column223:
you return one you don't want.

Players also land on Rummage! squares
column225: grab their letters and sprint off the the relevant room in the house. They then snatch objects from that room which start with the letter and return them to the game. So if you have the letter P and B and on the board are in the living room
column226: you might bring back a piano and a buffalo
column227:
or maybe just a pencil and a book if that's what you find.

Other squares get everybody Rummaging

column267:
The objective of this game is that as each player obtains sponsorship money they must invest it to build a Formula One racing team.

To do this
column268: the players complete four laps of the Game Board before entering the first Grand Prix. Whenever a player lands on Car
column271:
they can purchase these various elements to form a racing team.

Once a team has been formed
column272: players then complete one lap of The Jigsaw Board. The Jigsaw board consists of six double-sided track sections
column273:
which can be combined in various ways to create all sixteen circuits around which the players will race. Clever.

Players move their cars around each circuit in procession. No dice rolls. The mechanics of racing come from overtaking lanes
column274: which are positioned at critical points around the track. To overtake and improve your race position
column275:
you move your car into an overtaking lane and draw an overtaking card for either a straight and a corner. These cards list different elements that must be compared to the car you are overtaking.

For example
column276:
You succeed if CAR + ENGINE + ENGINEER ratings are higher.

This is the crux of the game. If you have assembled a team with high ratings then overtaking will succeed and therefore your team will succeed.
Whoever has the highest points after 16 races wins the championship.

engine blow-ups restarts etc… (From the back of the box)

Each player gets 2 cars
column317: not all cloned from one mold. It's a move-by-dice game with the die modified by cards you must pick up whenever you overtake an opponent on a bend. Mods include extra/lost spaces/turns

The lap is 39 spaces long and the track is only 1 space wide with only 2 cars allowed per space so there's going to be lots of blocking: however it is obviously a 'ladder' game and not one where skill predominates over other factors to any great extent. One of the cards takes out the car you're overtaking as well as yours! A couple force a race restart.... You can forgo part of your move by declining to overtake in some situations
column321:
to avoid picking up a card. A few spaces on the straights have optional card pickup as well.
Shame there's not a big skill factor

ALL THE ACTION OF GRAND PRIX RACING

column414:
players assume the roles of Swedish political party leaders and compete to form the nation's next government. There are 349 seats (mandates) up for grabs and the government can only be formed by a force with 175 or more seats.

On their turns
column415: the players move their pieces on the board.  Most of the spaces on the board are Profile spots that give seats to the controlling party.  Players contest for these spaces by participating in a closed bid
column416: using their Argument cards.  The values on their selected cards is added to the value of their party's color on the spot
column417: and the party with the higher total value wins the Profile.  Players can also moving their pieces to the TV debates spot and try to bluff their way to win more seats.  The Chance spots instruct players to draw a Chance card
column418: making them win or lose seats
column419:
or even swap electorates. Players are free to wheel and deal in this game.

The game ends when all seats have been distributed. The winner is the leader whose party has the required majority. If no one has a majority
column420:
two players can join forces to achieve the required number and be joint winners.

Components list:
1 x Rulebook
1 x Gameboard
4 x Plastic standees (1 in each players color)
72 x Chans cards
20 x Profil cards
15 x Minister cards
4 x 27 Argument cards (divided in the 4 player colors)
397 mandates (349 + extras according to the rules)in
24 x Larger plastic 10 mandates
156 x Smaller plastic 1 mandates

column432:
Bondespelet ("The Farmer Game") or occasionally Nya Bondespelet ("The New Farmer Game") is a Swedish classic roll-and-move game about farmers and farming. You win by being the first farmer who buys the castle. The journey goes from a croft via a farm to a manor and ends with the castle (UK: Stately home).

The game features a roll-and-move style of movement around the board
column433:
success relying on having your marker stopping on the good spaces so you get crop markers that you can sell later on. Farms and forests are bought and sold by the money you earn from the events and crops.

Though being an absolute classic in Sweden
column434: and one of the flagships for the game publisher Alga
column435: very little is known of this game's origin. It has seen at least four graphically major remakes since the first version. It's rumoured to be as old as the 40s
column436:
at least we know that the game existed in 1951.

The now defunct publisher AB Sago-Konst is rumoured to be the first publisher. When they in the 1950's became
column437: or became part of (history is unclear here)
column438: AB Grafisk konst the latter published another more or less identical version. They were followed by Aristospel with yet another more or less identical version. Since approx. 1974 Alga (currently owned by Brio
column439:
itself owned by Ravensburger) has published this game in about half a dozen editions.

See the information tab on the various versions for details about them.

A collection of 21 excellent games that are guaranteed to keep everyone guessing

From the introductory card:

"This pack contains rules to 21 different late night games.

These games are perfectly suited to late-night revellers who just don't want the party to end: a few drinks have been drunk and inhibitions are starting to slip yet some people still have some sort of control over their limbs. These are games which encourage everyone to get to know each other just a little bit better. No-one would dream of playing them in the clear light of day of course

but market traders and merchant bankers alike all need to let their hair down sometimes and this is the ideal opportunity. So loosen your clothing and let's get playing!"

column494: Kemps (also known as Canes) is played with two two-person teams. (You could play with three or four teams
column495: but it becomes more complicated.)  Each player is dealt a hand of 4 cards from a standard deck
column496: and then the Dealer deals four cards face-up to the center of the table.  If you're right-handed
column497: you should keep your hand (of cards) in your left hand
column498:
and vice-versa -- this is because you are only allowed to use one hand to pick up or put down cards.

When everyone is ready
column500: at which point the round starts.  Play is simultaneous
column501: with no turns.  Your goal is to have all four cards in your hand of the same value (i.e. all 4 kings
column502: or all 4 deuces).  If a card you want is on the table
column505: and then discard a card to replace it.  If the action comes to a standstill because noone wants any of the cards on the table
column508:
and says "Begin" again.

When you have acquired a complete set
column510: but you cannot declare this yourself.  Instead
column511: you must use a pre-arranged signal to inform your partner (which must be "over the table" -- no kicking your partner in the shins!)
column512: who then announces "Kemps".  You show your hand
column513: and your team gets a point.  If you or your partner misread the signal and call Kemps erroneously
column514: the other team gets a point.  If you think you have spotted the other team's signal
column516: and name the player you think has Kemps.  If you are correct
column518: otherwise the other team does.  When someone has figured out the other team's signal
column519:
that team can go somewhere private to come up with a new one.

Play until any agreed-upon number of points.

column527: Caveat Emptor is vaguely real-estate themed
column528: with the board depicting a 7x7 array of lots
column529: divided into sections of different sizes and shapes.  Each lot is also marked with a Roman numeral from I-V.  Players have sets of cards with the same numbers - on each round every player selects a card to be auctioned
column530: but these are all shuffled together so no one knows exactly what will be available.  The gimmicks are that the winner of each auction can choose any like-numbered lot to own
column531: and that the winning bid goes to the person who played the card

but no one knows who that is until the auctions are over.

Each lot has an intrinsic value based on the size of the section it is in
column533: the bigger the section the more valuable.  However
column534: a player can double or triple the value of his or her lots in a section by owning a majority or all of them

etc. The winner can ask the oracles a question.

""
column765: Deguello ! The War of Texan Independence
column773:
From the designer: "In 1835 men from all over the world came together to a little mission located in the Mexican province of Texas. It was called the Alamo and the deeds that occurred there in early March helped to shape the destiny of the United States of America. But the Alamo was only the most famous of the battles that occurred during the Texas War of Independence. And now with Deguello you can recreate history and relive the sharp struggle for Texas independence.

By generating the scenarios for you
column774:
DEGUELLO lets you link all your combats into one long continuous story. Easy to learn game mechanics and a unique "reaction system" combine to make every game different.

Set an ambush
column777:
it’s all here for you. Playable with any already based figures DEGUELLO can be played solo or with others.

The Mexican band strikes up the “Deguello”
column778:
the Spanish tune for “no quarter”. The battle is about to begin. Are you ready?"

Simple miniatures game for Texas War of Independence.

""
column791:
From the designer: "Man to man combat and campaign system in the Old West. Fast play and easy to learn Six Gun Sound kicked off the man to man combat games that have become known as the Mayhem series. Not only does Six Gun Sound provide a realistic "quick & deadly" combat system it also has a campaign system. The campaign is centered around the old Southwest and includes Kansas and Texas. The system easily links the various gunfights together to tell the story of the Old West. To see a review of Six Gun Sound press here...."

Skirmish miniature combat for the Wild West.
column802: This is Truly a 4 player chess game that works and is fun to play! It can be played in 2
column803:
3 or 4 player mode. With 2 or 4 players you play with 4 sets of pieces and the pieces opposite to each other are partners or teams. The object is to checkmate the other team Kings... so you need 2 checkmates to win ... or a checkmate and a stalemate to win! The Beauty of this game is when your team first gets checkmated you don't lose all that players pieces! Depending on what configuration everyone agreed on at the start of the game determines what pieces are removed when a checkmate occurs. So everybody stays in the game.... right to the end! Piece movement is the same as traditional 2 player chess... with just a few variations that are easy to learn.

""
column812: Otto Walkes is a famous German cartoonist and this game features his Ottifants (http://www.ottifant.de/). An evil wizard has trapped a princess in a tower and turned her family into frogs. Your Ottifant must climb up and reach out to kiss her with its trunk
column813:
hinder by the wizards raven and helped by a kind witch.

Players roll special dice and follow the actions indicated
column814:
gradually extending their Ottifants truck. Kissing a frog converts it back into an Ottifant which helps your reach the Princess.

""
column823: In The Trap! - An early Kramer game
column824: you must pass through the forest and avoid the pitfalls laid by the thieves. Play is by rolling dice numbered 0-3 with 2 special moves. The board includes a turntable which is rotated and if red spaces turn up
column826:
with nearly enough to engage the adult player.

""
column835: An early abstract 2 player game from Alex Randolph
column836: players move a pipe of chips across the board
column837: which fall into the available spaces. The board is a plastic table with 6x6 depressions
column838:
but the 4 corners are blocked so there are only 32 playing spaces. One player seeds the board with 11 grey discs.

Then each player fills a plastic tube with wooden discs
column840: the other with yellow discs. One player starts in the corner and moves the tube. If it goes over an empty space
column841: the disc falls and occupies the place. The other player can choose to then take this tube
column843: so removing the starting advantage. The players then continue to move their tubes around
column844: until one gets 11 discs down for the win. The tubes can be moved orthogonally or diagonally any distance
column845:
but not jump or turn corners.

Reportedly a good abstract game and a clever physical mechanism.

""
column854: Corx is a dexterity game played with two cork cylinders (basically wine-bottle corks
column855: but precisely manufactured and with amusing characters painted on the sides -- this is where the 'collectible' aspect comes in
column856:
but other than the art every cork is the same).

Players take turns dropping the corks onto the table
column857: attempting to land them on their ends.  A cork that lands with the red end up is worth one point
column858: the black end up is worth 2 (because the black end is wider).  The player who gets exactly 21 points first wins; if you go over 21
column867: Lucky Chess is a card-based chess variant.  The cards are divided into decks based on which type of piece they apply to
column868: and on your turn you draw one.  This indicates from where (rank or file) you are allowed to move a piece
column869:
or whether or not you must make a capture.

The rules for three players involve two boards with a single White player and two Black players - White makes the same move on both boards simultaneously if possible.

""
column877: Mindz is an abstract ostensibly themed around colored rays of light on a mirrored board
column878: but the mechanics are not informed by this (the board is shiny
column879:
though).

Each player controls a set of pieces in different colors
column880: with the color indicating the number of spaces it can move in a turn.  Moves can be made in any combination of directions.  Each player also has a black piece ("black beam of light
column881:
" it says here - interesting concept) which starts the game trapped by the opponent. The object of the game is to free your black piece and bring it to your edge of the board.

Rules are included for three and four-player versions. In each two players team up
column882:
and on each team one player plays
attack and the other defense
column891: Doublethink is based on a puzzle
column892: namely to place three copies each of eleven letters (those in "Doublethink
column893:
" naturally) on a figure consisting of three concentric circles joined by eleven radial lines so that every letter is connected to every other one exactly once.

When played as a two-player game
column894:
each player gets fifteen letter chips (the remaining three being placed on the board) and places one at a time in an effort to form connections and make it impossible for the opponent's chips to be placed. A player scores a point for each connection he or she makes and also for each connection the opponent is prevented from making. The score can be read from an erasable board (the game also includes a pen) which tracks the connections made for each letter.

""
column902: Poka-Tile is a very simple adaptation of poker to a boardgame.  There are 108 square tiles depicting a double deck of cards plus jokers.  Each player has 4 tiles in hand (on a rack) at a time and must play them to form a row of exactly 5 tiles (the first player has a bonus space to play from).  Extra tiles are discarded
column903: so there is no hand management aspect.  Rules are provided for draw and 7-tile variants
column904:
neither of which adds much to the basic idea.

""
column913:
Ingenuity is an interesting attempt from an obscure Israeli company at a Mastermind/Black Box type deduction game (where one player sets up a puzzle and the other solves it) with a murder mystery theme.

The setter decides which of the 8 characters was murdered
column915: and with what weapon.  Clues to these elements are attached to the characters (for example
column916: whether the killer was male or female
column918:
etc.) and the pieces placed on the board. The murderer can have a false clue.

The solving player moves a detective figure around the board (which shows the floor plan of a small mansion and garden) encountering characters and looking at their clues. The setter gets turns to move characters to get away (presumably) from the detective. The object is to solve the mystery in as few turns as possible - as in other games of this type it is always played twice
column919:
with the roles reversed for the second game.

The pieces really make the game - the characters are large Lucite blocks with simple pictures on the fronts and metal circles on the backs - the clues are on small magnets which attach to the circles. In addition
column920:
a piece of red plastic is provided to serve as the pool of blood in which the victim is found.

""
column930: A Swedish strategy game in which players represent major European powers in a pseudo-WWII scenario.  The theater of war is Europe and North Africa
column931:
and the units are all land-based - Infantry and Armour.

Air and Naval units are provided for with the use of cards
column932: which also allow the use of special strategy and tactics (paratroopers
column945:
Cash and assets such as classic cars and oil paintings are traded with markets rising and falling constantly through the game.

The length of the game is predetermined by the players who can also decide whether to play haggle in its simplest form or amend and vary the rules in any way they can agree.

"Everything is negotiable...even the rules"
column954: The idea is to fill in as many words and names on your playing grid
column955:
against the timer. Each row begins with randomly chosen letters and there is a host of entertaining categories from "UK seaside resorts" to "creepy crawlies".

The trick is not to opt for the obvious answer - you'll chalk up extra points for words that nobody else has though of.

All you need is a dash of inspiration....

""

the edition presented here has minor rules changes and is named after the most important business magazine of Brazil.

""

column986:
whose movement are based in a combination of dice rolling and card drawing.

column995: Players are contestants in a dancing marathon.  Each turn they roll their dice and arrange them into two sequences of three dice (with one re-roll to try to change unwanted dice into something else).  These sequences are then compared to those of everyone else.  Higher difficulty dances (sequences) like the Tango or Tap Dance impress the judges.  Less accomplished dancers move down in ranking.  If they hit the bottom of the chart
column996:
they are out of the game. Certain sequences also convey special abilities such as not having to move down in ranking even if you are "out danced" by your competition.

The last dancer still standing wins!

From the English rules:

At the head office of Splotter-4-all computer services the phones just won't stop ringing: complaints galore! Everyone wants internet. Where are the connections?

WEB is a game in which the players attempt to connect as many computers as possible. More than anyone else at least. If that isn't possible by connecting more computers yourself there are other means. Stealing computers from your neighbors
column1021:
dumping uninteresting contracts on them...in WEB everything is allowed.

";;;;

telephones and the likes. Using colored sticks you connect them with ISDN-lines. You win by connecting the most valuable computers.

column1035: and well known legends. Extra advances are made by correctly spelling the word

column1038: and vowels are all correctly answered

and may advance or retreat on the board depending on the roll. The winning player is the first one to get to the end of the game board.

and gives it to the other player. In turn players can then either guess what individual symbols mean or make Mastermind-mind style guesses by providing test words of the same lengths as the telegram words and being told how many letters match.

Actually

The other game is called 3-D Target Checkers

Note that the "gametime" that produced this game is not the same one that produced Spellmaker

etc. - that one was a division of Heritage.

column1091: Cardz is a set of 78 letter cards.  There are three basic suits with 22 letters in each suit (one of everything except J

column1096:

Rules are included for a number of different games

column1099:
etc.). The game that isn't an adaptation of a card game is very similar to Upwords.

A Kidz Cardz set was also sold - this has the same deck and many of the same games

for example).

The background of the game is of some interest. It was invented by Hannah Cannon

column1104: is a former screenwriter who seems to be good at promotional activities.)  It was supposedly sold in places such as Waldenbooks and Bloomingdale's

but references to it are hard to find now.

column1117: Each player takes on the role of a "Geist Hunter" and the first to catch their set of Geists and get them safely to the underworld wins. To catch Geists
column1118: you need to lure them with an exact number of Zingiberi chips. These are earned by moving around the board and landing on numbered squares. The number lets you take or return a chip of that value

and this keeps things rowdy but also adds to the strategy. Chili Pepper cards also spice things up since the Geists don't usually like them.

OH cards consists of two decks of cards: 88 picture cards and 88 word cards. There are several games that can be played with the cards. Games typically involve the player placing a picture card upon a word card and drawing associations between the two.

From the instruction book:

"The OH cards lend themselves to many uses
column1134:
from lighthearted storytelling to insightful self-exploration. Each of the games included in the instruction book can accommodate technical variations that you may wish to devise to suit your own circumstances."

An interesting game that was a winner at the European Game Collectors Guild of 2003. A limited set of 300 have been made by Playme.de and were sold at Essen but also still available from their site.

The game board is nine by nine grid with some islands in certain cells. Each round
column1145: three parrots fly onto the board from directions based on die rolls. Players then select movement options from different-complex cards
column1146: and simultaneously decide how their ship will move. The Parrots fly and then the ships move
column1147: and when a ship "catches" a parrot it keeps it. But if later the ship moves across an island
column1148:
they lose a parrot as it flies off the ship to look for food. Whoever collects the most parrots by game end wins.

column1195: A "question and answer" game (as opposed to a "trivia" game) in which players score points by correctly answering questions from a wide range of topics including history
column1198: etc.  A card with 10 questions (five on a side) and three answers per question is placed onto the electric board.  On their turn

no points are scored. The player with the highest score after a set number of rounds wins the game.

Electro

From the box:
Repel is an intriguing new game played between two people on either side of a clear vertical board
column1212: using magnetized playing discs.  Players quickly learn how to use the magnetic forces of attraction and repulsion to their advantage

as their magnetic discs interact through the board.
Not from the box:

You may place discs so that they repel your opponent's piece off the board or in such a way that both his/her piece and your piece "attach" and become permanent. Each player also has two "Power Discs" which may not be repelled nor attached to.

ages 9-and-up.

From the instructions:

Each player picks a card and tries to successfully bid the highest number combination or cause an opponent to unsuccessfully bluff a number combination. The last bidder of each round moves its playing piece forward the number of spaces indicated on his card
column1240:
if his bid is successful. The player moves backwards that number of spaces if his bid is not successful. The first player to the finish line is the winner.

Cards consist of eight numbers from 1 through 10 (10 is 0) and may repeat. Bidding proceeds as:

Player #1 says "three-3's"
Player #2 says "four-2's"
Player #3 says "five-2's"
etc...

Consists of: 1 game board with a hexagon type "maze"

"During the Middle Ages feudalism determined much that happened in military terms

1314

column1277: The Great Muppet Caper Card Game
column1283: Card game based on the movie
column1284:
played in a series of rounds until one player has 21 points.

Each player has a hand of 12 cards. Seven of the cards match the seven spaces on the board
column1285:
which illustrate the story sequence of the movie. Four of the cards form a puzzle that shows the Baseball Diamond. One card is a thief card.

The players start with four cards in their hands and draw a card
column1286: then play a card each turn. There are four play options. A player may play a story card if it matches the next empty space on the board. A puzzle card may be played in front of the player. A thief card may be played against another player to have all of that player's puzzle card showing placed in a discard pile for that player. Finally
column1287: if a player cannot or does not want to play a card
column1288:
one can be placed directly into the discard pile.

A round ends when the last story card is played onto the board. Points are then tallied. Each player gets a point for each story card that was played to the board in this round. A point is also awarded for each puzzle card that is still face up in front of the player. A bonus point is awarded if the player has all four puzzle cards face up. A point is subtracted from each player who is still holding a thief card in hand.

Further rounds are played
column1289: with the player with the least total points going first in each round
column1290:
until at least one player has scored 21 or more points. The player with the most points wins.

column1295: The Powerpuff Girls: Mojo Jojo Attacks Townsville Game
column1303: One player controls the Powerpuff Girls
column1304: trying to stop Mojo Jojo from using his laser tower to destroy them and Townsville. The other player controls Mojo Jojo
column1305:
trying to take out the Powerpuff Girls. Each character has an individual deck of action cards. Players try to reduce opposing characters' hit points to KABLOOEY!

The Powerpuff Girls player selects a girl to activate and draws from the appropriate deck. The player will then follow the card instructions (usually movement). If the girl moves adjacent to Mojo Jojo
column1306: then she can fight him along with any other girls that are with her. Fighting Mojo Jojo consists of rolling one die for each girl in the fight.  Each die has 3 sides with no stars

Mojo Jojo loses one hit point.

The Mojo Jojo player draws a card from the Mojo Jojo deck and follows the instructions. Mojo Jojo may attack if adjacent to a Powerpuff Girl
column1309: rolling a black die that is the counterpart to the girls' dice

except with splats instead of stars. Then Mojo Jojo gets a second attack. The player throws a red die through the laser sight on the 3D Laser Tower to physically knock down one or more of the Powerpuff Girl figures. Each girl knocked down loses a hit point.

A Powerpuff Girl whose hit points are reduced to KABLOOEY! is out of the game and her figure and deck are removed. Mojo Jojo wins if all three Powerpuff Girls are removed from the game. The Powerpuff Girls win if Mojo Jojo's hit points are reduced to KABLOOEY!

column1407: Gates Skill is a connection game.  The board is an 8x8 array of holes
column1408: and the pieces are gates - effectively a line between one hole and an orthogonally adjacent one
column1409: with one end attached to a hole
column1410:
which it can rotate around.
The object is to have an unbroken series of your gates connecting two opposite sides of the board.

It's possible to capture opposing gates by surrounding them with yours and possibly the edge of the board.

The key gimmick is that
column1412: the gates can rotate.  On your turn you can rotate a gate instead of placing one
column1413:
and if you can win or capture by rotating gates you can rotate any number of them at once.

column1423: Murder is a somewhat unusual deduction game.  The equipment consists of a deck of (seemingly homemade but fairly sturdy) cards and a cloth bag.  The cards include a group of times
column1424: a number of opportunity cards (all identical)
column1425: a group of motives (all with appropriate quotes

column1428: and 10 sets of actual murder cards
column1436:
and Avenue.

Each player gets a You Are Murdered card and a random assortment of others
column1437: and in turn takes a card and discards one into the bag.  The last player in the round takes the bag and can select one of the cards
column1438:
discarding the rest face up (first player then rotates).

The object of this part is to collect a 4-card murder set plus a motive
column1440:
and time. When you have these you discard You Are Murdered and the last player in the round becomes the victim when that card is pulled from the bag.

At that point the game shifts into deduction mode
column1441: with everyone trying to deduce which player was the murderer and what his or her alias
column1443:
and time cards are.

Unfortunately the rules go very vague at this point - questioning is totally free-form
column1444: there is no way to score (and the end doesn't come until everyone has the solution
column1446: and they don't address the issue of what happens if there is more than one murderer.  However

it may be possible to invent new rules to fix these problems.

column1452: Hellenes: Campaigns of the Peloponnesian War
column1459: Hellenes: Campaigns of the Peloponnesian War (GMT Games) is 2 player game on the Peloponnesian War of the Greek classical age designed by Craig Besinque (EuroFront series). Based on a variant of the Hammer of the Scots/Liberty system

and lots of options for both players.

One player plays Sparta

and civic discord all play important roles.

the lost battle reduces the besieger's prestige!

column1500:
is in the similar vein as Spades and Bridge as a trick taking game. Play uses a standard deck of 52 cards. Players partner with the player across from them and are each dealt 9 cards.

The bid begins to the dealer's left at a minimum of four points and goes around the table
column1501: with players increasing the bid based on what they think they can take; if everyone passes the bid
column1502: the dealer is required to take the bid at four.  The player who announces the highest bid takes the position of dealer/leader and calls the trump suit
column1503: which is the only suit of import in this game (excepting the jokers and the left bauer or off-jack [jack of the same color
column1504: but not the trump suit]).  All players
column1506: discard all the cards from their hands that are not of the trump suit and request enough cards from the remaining 18-card deck to bring their hand up to 6. (*Note: If a player mistakenly discards a trump card
column1507: or one of the three other special cards
column1508: it is a free-for-all to whomever notices and picks it up off the table first)  The remaining cards in the deck are given to the bid-winner/leader
column1509: who can pick through them one-by-one
column1510: and pass any remaining unseen cards to his partner
column1511:
each of them discarding to 6 before play begins.

Play begins with the dealer/leader leading in the trump suit. Play proceeds around the table
column1512: with the player playing the highest valued card taking the trick and leading the following trick.  Players may only play cards that are of the trump suit
column1513: other remaining cards are useless. If a player takes a trick and no longer has cards of the trump suit
column1515: and the player to the left then begins the trick.  Cards are ranked from Ace to Two
column1518:
and Low Joker respectively taking the positions between the Jack and Ten.

Points are accrued by teams for taking the point cards in the tricks they take
column1523: Low Joker (one has to rank higher than the other for play continuity)
column1526: and Two.  All are worth a point apiece
column1528:
which is worth three. The two is retained by the player who played it for his or her team and is not taken along with the trick.

Both teams receive points for the point cards they take
column1529: unless the high-bidding team does not meet their bid goal
column1530:
in which case they go "set" and lose their number of bid points instead of gaining. Teams play to 52 points.

Another option to bidding played in some areas is to "shoot the moon." Shooting the moon means taking all 10 points. If the bid is shoot the moon the bidding team advances their score to 52 if their score was above zero or to zero if their score was below zero. Failure to score all ten points constitutes loss of game.


Another version
column1534:
and Game plays with hands of 6 cards.

There are four possible points in a hand:

High: highest trump card in play
Low: lowest trump card in play; this point is retained by the team that played it regardless of who takes the trick
Jack: Jack of trump
column1535:
if in play
Game: highest point total in tricks captured counting A - 4
column1539:
and 10 - 10.


Variant - 6 point pitch: Jokers Add in high and low Jokers for a point each if in play. Their strength is between Jack and 10. They are always considered to be in the trump suit



Starting at the dealer's left
column1540: each player has one chance to bid
column1541: with a minimum bid of 2. Players can overbid a previous bid. The person who wins the bid gets to name trump. Dealer has to take the bid if everyone passes

column1545:
and will have to go 3.

If you bid and don't make it
column1546:
you go down that many points. You can make points if your opponents bid.

After the bid and declaration of trump
column1547:
some people allow trashing and getting up to 2 new cards.

The player who won the bid leads a trump card. After that

column1573:
Crown Red is played on an eleven by eleven board. Each space is either a white or black circle. The goal is to be the first player to move their crowned king onto the red home space opposite from where it started.

Each player starts with one uncrowned king and two pawns. On each turn a player moves one piece 5 spaces in order that the gravity selector shows.

The gravity selector contains ten black or white marbles in a clear column with a red base. At the beginning of a turn the player inverts the gravity selector and then returns it to its upright position. For example
column1574: the selector shows WBBWB. A piece must be moved first to a white circle. Next to a black circle and so on. A piece can be moved forward
column1575:
backward or sideways.

Before a king can moved home
column1576:
he must possess a red crown (small red marble). A king earns a crown when the player captures an opponents piece. Kings can be captured which results in the king losing its crown and returns to its start position.

column1643:
From Bruno Faldetti's Review:

The name sounds like a Japanese war cry
column1644: and the game looks a bit like Go. With its large square box and its flat black box
column1645: Ooyoo could have been one of these strange games that we used to look with eagerness and curiosity in the Impensé Radical bookshop
column1647: in the late seventies and early eighties. Yes
column1648: I know I'm getting old. Nothing oriental though in this game
column1650:
and author and publisher both German.

Ooyoo
column1652: is what it looks like : a simple and subtle strategy game
column1654: that could well become a classic. Like in Halma or Chinese Checkers
column1655: each player starts in a corner of the board and tries to bring all his stones in the opposite corner. The trick is in the simple and original movement rule : stones can only move by pair
column1656: two adjacent stones moving one space in the same direction. This makes for various blocking and turning strategies
column1657: especially since each player has an uneven number of stones
column1658:
and can't move backwards in his own half of the board.

Ooyoo is much more subtle than Chinese Checkers
column1659: but doesn't pretend to be as deep and as Go - the similarity is mostly in the overall look. This excellent strategy game deserves to become a modern classic
column1662: and can also make for a nice and slightly lighter change for Go or Chess players. Furthermore
column1663: it really looks like an exotic traditional game that you brought back from holidays

and will make a strong impression in your lounge.

column1677:
1863

the fall of Washington served only to radicalize & galvanize the North.

and announced they would join the war to secure its independence.

leading them in an attack on Vienna.

With the CSA
column1696:
World War I began in August 1863. "Home Before the Leaves Fall" was the cry heard across the northern hemisphere.

Lee convinced Jefferson Davis to reinforce him by shifting troops fromBragg;'s Army to create a 4th Corps for the Army of Northern Virginia. Comprised of Tennessee men & recruits from the new Confederate state of Maryland

Gen. Pat Cleburne was picked to run it. Lee intended to use the new Corps as a screen for his next offensive.

With the fall of Vicksburg
column1699: Lee reasoned Gen.Sherman would move east to relieve the Union's fortunes. If he could intercept Sherman & destroy his army before it linked with Grant's
column1700: the war would surely end. Scanning his maps
column1701: Lee determined Pittsburgh was the key. If he controlled it
column1702:
he would sever the only east / west rail line left to the Union. It was also the perfect place to meet the British (actually Anglo-Canadian) Expeditionary Force forming in Canada for a crossing of Lake Erie.

Lee sent an outline of his plan to the Commander of the BEF
column1705:
sending a reply in which he promised to rendezvous with lee at Pittsburgh on or around October 1.

Until 14 September
column1706: Grant & Lincoln had assumed Lee's next move would be in the Northeast. On that day a minister of the Canadian government
column1708: defected with a copy of the Confederate general's letter. After much debate
column1709: the two US war leaders convinced themselves the document was authentic & set about to counter Lee's plan. The 3rd Corps was left to defend the Susquehanna River line
column1711:
and a telegram was sent to Sherman instructing him to move to Pittsburgh as quickly as possible.

By the 17th
column1712: when Lee began marching northeast towards Pittsburgh
column1713: Grant had already stolen a day's march on him. The question became who would get to the city first to meet Lee & Grant: the BEF
column1714: shuttling across Lake Erie then marching down the western borderlands of Pennsylvania
column1716: coming up the Ohio valley. Neither Grant nor Lee knew who would be reinforced first or exactly when
column1717:
but both understood there would be a savage fight for Pittsburgh. It would go into southern history books as the Battle of Six Bridges.

column1933:
There are sixty vampires chits; ten vampires each of six different colors. The vampires are shuffled face down and distributed evenly among the players. Each player lines up one’s own vampires and reveals the identity of the vampires on both ends. The grave lids have the same distribution of colors as the vampires with the addition of six lids which have rats on them. Six lids are randomly removed and temporarily set aside from the rest and replaced with the lids with the rats on them. The lids are shuffled thoroughly then each lid is placed face down on one of the hollow graves on the game board. Each player receives three garlic chits of a unique color.

Each player in turn turns over a grave lid. If the color of the obverse side of the lid matches the color of the vampire on either end of one’s own line then the player may put the vampire in the grave. If the grave is empty and the color of the lid does not match either vampire on the player’s ends then the player may place a garlic chit in the empty grave and replace the lid.

If the grave already contains a vampire then receives a wooden stake. When a player collects three wooden stakes all the other players give one of their vampires to that player. Should the grave contain garlic placed by another player
column1934:
then the player who placed the garlic gives a vampire to player who found it. A player who finds one’s own garlic receives one vampire from each of the players.

Revealing a grave lid with a rat allows a player the option to reveal the grave lids of the surrounding graves.

The game continues until one player has gotten rid of all of one’s own vampires. That player is the winner.

column1962:
BlackJack originated in French casinos around 1700 where it was called "vingt-et-un" and has been played in the U.S. since the 1800's.

Blackjack is played with a standard deck of 52 playing cards. In a Casino
column1963: usually six (6) or eight (8) decks of cards are shuffled together and placed in a card shoe for distribution.  The player must wager before any cards are dealt. He does this by placing his bet in front of his table position. Next
column1964: the dealer deals two cards to each of the players and two to himself. (One of the dealer's cards is dealt face up
column1965: one is dealt face down). Face cards count as ten
column1967:
and all other cards are counted at their face value.

A blackjack occurs if the player's first two cards are an ace and a ten or face card. This is usually a winning hand
column1968: although if the dealer also has a blackjack
column1969:
it is a tie. A winning blackjack pays the player three to two.

The dealer must draw on 16 and stand on 17. (A dealer total of 17 including an ace
column1971:
must be drawn to in some games and must stand in others). Options:

Hit or Stand - Hit means to draw another card
column1972: which the player signifies by tapping the table with his cards or a similar hand motion. Stand means that the player wants no more cards
column1973: which the player signals by placing his cards under his wager or holding his hand in a horizontal direction. If the player hits and busts (goes over 21)
column1974:
his wager is lost.

Double down - The player is allowed to double his original bet on his first two cards
column1975:
then draw one more card.

Splitting - If the first cards a player is dealt are a pair
column1976: they may be split into two hands which are played separately. The bet on each hand must be the same amount. Aces receive only one card. After splitting
column1978:
and not as blackjack.

Insurance - A bet not exceeding one-half of the original bet. When the dealer's up card is an ace
column1979: the player may take insurance. If the dealer's down card is a ten or face card
column1980:
the player wins two to one. Any other card means a win for the dealer.

Surrender - To give up after the deal of the first two cards. Only one-half of the original bet is lost. Not all blackjack games offer surrender.

When not playing at a casino
column1981:
it is usual for the role of Dealer to rotate among the players.

Pontoon is a similar game
column1982: but there are some small rules variations. For example
column1983:
the dealer wins on ties and both of their cards are dealt face down.

column2288: A 2 player abstract game using a board made from separate square tiles
column2289: with channels at right angles to control movement
column2290: on both sides of each tile. Players must get 4 of their 5 pieces across the board and can rotate a tile 90 degrees each turn. The trick in the game is that you can move on the paths over the tiles
column2291: then move on the paths underneath the tiles
column2292:
then move again on the surface.

There are two kinds of tile. One tile has the right angle paths in the same place on both sides. The other tile has them on different places on each side. This works because you can tell by the markings which paths are on the underside without having to look. The board is set up randomly in a 5x7 grid.

When travelling underneath
column2293: you must travelling under at least one stone on the surface
column2294: of either player. If you do go under an opponent's stone
column2295: you are allowed a further tile rotation at the end of your move (a key bonus that gives you an edge). You are not allowed to move a tile that your opponent just turned
column2296:
but otherwise you can rotate any tile at all.

The new edition by Abacus is in card
column2297: with little wood posts to help lift and turn the tiles. The first edition is a nice wooden edition
column2298:
part of a range of games by the firm Clemens Gerhards.

Moguli seems like a brain-burner at first
column2299: but quickly the possibilities become obvious
column2300: and as only a few tiles move
column2301: you can read the paths on both sides very easily. You move from trying to figure the board
column2302: to trying to figure your opponent's options and how to exploit them. Moguli is a very interesting abstract that seems gimmicky at first
column2303:
but soon becomes a clever challenge and very entertaining.

Players are knights trying to save princess Pimpernell from the dragons' cave.

A facedown track of tiles is laid out between the knights' castle and the dragons' lair. Each player controls three knights of different sizes.
The active player rolls has two options:
- roll all three dice (which correspond to the knights) and move the knights in any direction. If a knight lands on an armor tile
column2422: the player has to say what armor it is. If correct
column2425:
the tile is returned.
- or look at an armor tile.
If a knight lands on a dice tile
column2426: the player can re-roll the corresponding die. On plain tiles
column2427: nothing happens. When a knight lands on a tile with another player's knight of the same size
column2428:
that knight is sent back to the castle.

A player who moves a knight into the dragons' lair flips over one of the dragon tiles there. The back side of the dragon tiles shows a piece of armor. If the player has such an armor tile
column2429: s/he defeats the dragon and wins the game. If not

The players begin the game with 5 road tiles in hand and each turn they draw a new one. After laying down their first tile
column2636: they extend their road network each turn by playing a tile to continue the road from the tile played in the previous turn.  Players can also take their turn to play their tiles on their opponent's road.  If a player is unable to continue from a tile played in the previous turn
column2637:

The game also ends when all tiles have been drawn and played. If no players have not completed a road in the manner mentioned before

and division.

Start Trek: The Motion Picture license published in book form with punch out pieces.

_____________________________________

In fact

or engage in your own piracy—the big bucks are for those who can smuggle past orbital customs stations.

Use your credits to upgrade your space freighter and find other special equipment. Freedom of movement and diversity of choice don't keep Smugglers of the Galaxy from being a simple and easy play.

Some of the many options for players include: Space Trading
column4089:
and Starship Upgrades.

SPACE TRADING
Every planet has different demands for Food
column4093:
and Medical Supplies. Buy low on one world and sell high on another. Expand your ship’s cargo capacity and upgrade your Lightspeed to make credits quick—but watch out for pirates on the space lanes.

SMUGGLING
Some goods are illegal on some worlds—but that means big bucks for those who can smuggle them past customs! Larger worlds generally have larger starports—which means better security but also better profits. Crime Bosses offer the biggest payoffs but you’ll regret it if you fail them. Find friends and technology that will help you smuggle because you don’t want to get caught with a shipload of illegal goods.

PIRACY
Become a space pirate yourself by arming your ship and blasting unsuspecting merchant ships (and other players) for their cargo. Be careful though—as your bounty stacks up
column4094:
tougher bounty hunters will become interested in you.

BOUNTY HUNTING
So other players have bounties on their heads? Go after them and collect! But making powerful enemies in the galaxy may be your undoing. A good bounty hunter must know when and where to strike.

UPGRADE YOUR SPACESHIP
Whether peaceful merchant

By the beginning of 1954
column4275: both French and Viet Minh realized that the war in Indochina was nearing an end. Ho Chi Minh had requested cease-fire negotiations in Geneva
column4277:
and the French government was looking for a way out that would give them peace with honor. Both sides felt that a "big win" on the battlefield would finally secure at the peace table what they had been unable to obtain in six and a half years of war.

The site of this battle would be near a village called
column4279: "Seat of the Border County Prefecture" located in a distant valley of north-western Vietnam near the Laotian border. The French high command

column4611: This card game consists of two decks: a deck of topics and a deck of consonants. Both decks are shuffled and five consonants are dealt. The first consonant may not be used by the players in their word but the other consonants may be used and are assigned values of one
column4612:
two or three. The topic is read aloud and the players must think up a word that fits the topic and uses any or all of the permissible consonants but not the forbidden consonant. The first to think up a word announces it and totals its value. The other players then secretly decide whether anyone else can come up with a higher scoring word. Once the players have voted anyone who thinks a higher scoring can been generated has an additional twenty seconds (a sand timer is included) to announce that word. Points are scored based on who came up with the round's winning word and who voted correctly.

The final round of the game has the players deciding which of two teams to join secretly. The player who comes up with the highest scoring word on each team scores the most points.

The player with the most points at the end of the game is the winner.

column4782: Easiest description is likely that this game plays similar to Spades.  It uses a regular deck of 52 playing cards

with Aces high and a trump suit (declared in 7-4-1 versus always spades in Spades).

In 7-4-1
column4785: 12 cards are dealt to each of the 4 players; this leaves a 4-card kitty.  The dealer MUST try to take 7 tricks
column4786: but she gets to declare which suit is trump AFTER looking at her hand.  She then gets to pick up the 4 middle cards

and player 4 need not take any.

After round 1
column4791: figure out how many cards more or less players got.  YOu get one point for every trick you make above your required tricks
column4792: and lose one for every trick you fail to make.  For the next round
column4793:
a player who had MORE in the previous round can then pass one card per amount more to a player who had less; that lesser player must then pass their HIGHEST card in each requested suit. Some pre-defined ordering for this is necessary; the player needing to make the most tricks has precedence over the player needing less.

For example
column4796: the position 2 is now the new dealer.  Player in position 3 was +2 in round 1 (took 3
column4798: and would ask position 1 for 1 suit
column4799: and position 2 for 1 suit.  Player in position 4 would then ask position 2 for 1 suit.  We've played where if the numbers over/under match (position 3&2
column4801:
then they could simply swap cards too.

Play then proceeds as described above. Trump is declared AFTER the card-swapping is done. And if the player who needed 4 in the previous round took NONE
column4802: then they can also look at the kitty too before declaring a trump!  However
column4803:
they'd also have just given up 4 good cards to other players...\
Game ends after either 2 or 3 rounds
column4804:
with everyone getting a chance at each position an equal number of times.

column4847:
This abstract game consists of five concentric rings divided into sixteen sectors (bars). Each player has a home sector that is four bars wide. Ten directional playing pieces start in the center bars of the home sector facing outwards. Each turn players roll two dice and use each dice roll to move a piece either in its facing direction or along its bar. When a piece starts a turn outside of it home sector and then is moved within the sector it is removed from the game. The first player to run out of pieces wins the game.

Additional complexity comes from blocking
column4848: capturing (freezing pieces while simultaneously preventing other opposing pieces from entering the bar in which the capture occurs)
column4849:
removing pieces from the board through `ringers' and special moves from rolling doubles. Variant rules exist for more cutthroat games and games with more than two players.

SherCo was the first of its kind to be played on a game board representing a composite stadium with a 28 x 28 numbered square grid. It also was the first to rate every player who played in at least one game in a season; and it was the first to provide its unique rating formulae so that customers could rate their own players and teams.

column5005: and home runs allowed. In the SherCo Plus versions
column5006:
pitcher ratings include batting average against ratings to further refine pitcher vs. batter control and the accuracy of statistical outcomes.

All versions of SherCo GrandSlam Baseball (Plus and Classic) still have all of these unique features (including a wind factor; automatic umpire; artificial turf rules; injuries
column5009: and error charts; and playing pieces representing the ball
column5012: and base runners so that you can position players exactly where you want them to play and watch every play unfold right before your eyes. There are also Fast Action Charts included with each season to get one-roll accurate results for games between other teams as you complete a season for your favorite team.  The new SherCo Plus variant has expanded pitcher-batter-runner ratings and offers many more realistic play results per chart
column5013:
including rarities such as catcher's interference.

Each dice-activated result allows a patented "stop-action effect" to visually occur when a probable hit or probable out batted ball is plotted on a specific square on the stadium's playing field. As the runners advance

column5015: fields it and throws to where you want the ball to go in a quick
column5016: seamless sequence of turns.  A ball may drop in for a hit or become an out depending on where it is hit
column5017: the strength and direction of the wind
column5018: and where a defensive player is positioned. Depending on where you are playing

will it drop in or will the fielder have enough time to make a fantastic catch?).

A solitaire or head-to-head game takes only 30-45 minutes to play
