column13116:
Vietnam Battles: Hue and Operation Pegasus

These two games
column13118:
were both were major battles of the 1968 Tet Offensive in The Republic of South Vietnam.

Hue simulates the fighting for the old Vietnamese capital at Hue. This was one of the longest and most intense battles of the 1968 Tet Offensive. Hue has two scenarios. The Standard scenario covers the first stage of the battle. The Extended scenario follows the fighting all the way through to the final Allied victory. Both scenarios are set up in the same way.

Operation Pegasus simulates the operations surrounding the U.S. Marine Corps firebase at Khe Sanh. The game has two scenarios. The Lang Vei scenario starts with the Communist assault which overran the Lang Vei Special Forces camp and includes the possibility of a fullscale Communist assault on Khe Sanh itself. The Relief scenario covers the airmobile attackby the U.S. First Cavalry Division (Airmobile) which relieved Khe Sanh. Each Pegasus Scenario has separate deployment instructions and victory conditions.

The Vietnam Battles game system is a grand tactical simulation of combat during the Indochina Wars. Each game in the system represents a major battle between Allied and Communist forces. The playing pieces represent the aütual units which participated in the battles. The maps represent the terrain over which those units fought.

Several key factors of Vietnam War operations are simulated
column13119: including the interaction of conventional and guerrilla forces
column13121: and the utilization of helicopters and airpower. There are two players. One represents the Communists (Viet Cong and North Vietnamese Army); the other the Allies (United States
column13123:
and others).

The rules are divided into the Standard Rules
column13124: which are common to all games in the system and the Exclusive Rules
column13126:
reinforcement and . victory instructions for each specific battle. The standardization of rules makes it easier for the gamer to play games within the series. Certain rules are designated Optional. This means the players may utilize them at their discretion; optional rules are not necessary • for the play of the game. Optional mies add additional complexity.

Released with Strategy & Tactics magazine #196 (March/April 1999).

Game Scale:
Hue
Game Turn: 1 day
Hex: .31 miles / 500 meters
Units: Company to Battalion

Pegasus
Game Turn: 2 days
Hex: .62 miles / 1 kilometer
Units: Company to Battalion

One 22 x 34" full color map
One dual-side printed countersheet (280 1/2" counters)
One 16-page rulebook

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 4-15 hours

Players will need to provide one 6-sided die for game play.

On subsequent turns the player rolls two dice to get zero to two additional magic stones (there are 12 in the castle in addition to the one in the fields).

The nature of a raven's current square determines the type of turn in has; in each case the player must guess a colour which will determine move distance. On one type of field dice are rolled and spots in the guessed colour determine movement distance. Another has a second player draw two cards and select one

From Pagat:

This is a card game in the Barbu family. It uses a standard deck and has four subgames (Queen of Spades
column14242:
Tricks and FanTan).

Queen of Spades: the object is to avoid taking the Queen of Spades. Players who win a trick on which the QoS is played pays the bank $100.

Last 2: Avoid winning the next-to-last and the last tricks. The player who takes next-to-last trick pays $50 to bank; Player who takes the last trick pays $100 to bank.

Tricks: The banker gives the appropriately marked chip to the winner of each trick. At the completion of play
column14243: each player adds the numbers on his chips and multiplies this total by $10. This dollar amount is what the player receives from the bank. For example
column14247:
then he would receive $160 from the bank (1+4+11 = 16 x $10 = $160). The 1st trick is worth $10; $20 for 2nd; $30 for 3rd; etc.

FanTan: Play all of one's cards before any other player can play all of his. The bank pays $100 to the player which is the 1st Out; Bank pays $50 to 2nd Out; 3rd Out receives nothing and pays nothing; 4th Out pays $50 to bank; 5th Out pays $75 to bank; 6th Out pays $100 to bank; 7th Out pays $125 to bank; 8th Out pays $150 to bank.

column14275:
This abstract game consists of:
- One board with 37 “holes” in an hexagonal pattern
- 37 pieces (similar to Go-stones) in following color distribution: 1 silver; 4 white; 8 red; 8 blue; 8 yellow; 8 green.

The stones are randomly distributed in the holes of the board. Then players take their turns moving the silver stone in an adjacent not-empty hole and capturing the stones which is contained in that hole. White stones are worth 10 points each. Red
column14277: yellow and green stones are worth the square of their number (e.g.: if you capture 3 red stones
column14278: you get 9 points; if you capture 5 green stones
column14280:
and so on…).
Play continues until the silver stone is isolated (e.g.: it is surrounded only by empty holes).

In a game with 3 or more players
column14281: the final score of every player is given by the sum of the stones he/she captured
column14282: PLUS the sum of the stones captured by the following player. Hence the name Gute Nachbarn

she must place a marker (often little colored plastic trains that come with the game) on their train which allows others to play on her train temporarily until the marker is removed.

As soon as one player is out of dominoes

column14405:
From The Complete Book of Indoor Games by Peter Arnold:

Klabberjass is probably best known in America than in England
column14406: because under the names of Clabber
column14410: it occurs in Damon Runyon's amusing stories
column14411: and in 1937 a variation of the game
column14412: jo-jotte was publicized by Ely Culbertson. Despite the simularity of names it is not idenical with the Hungarian game of kalabrias
column14413: which is a game for three or four players. There may have been a common ancestor
column14414: or possibly the game was taken to the New World by Central European immigrants and there bowdlerized version of kalabrias. (Exeter Books
column14415:
1984)

Klabberjass is played in the North American and Great Britain with the 32 card deck. (6s
column14419: and 2s removed from the standard 52 card deck.) The trump suit enjoys the strange ranking of the Jass genre: J 9 A 10 K Q 8 7. Non trump suit rank A 10 K Q J 9 8 7 as in the Skat-Pinochle family. Six cards are dealt to each player and a card is turned up. Non-dealer then begins a bidding round to first to accept the turn-up as trump. Or pass. If both pass on the turn-up card a second round is held. Here the non-dealer may take the bid by naming one of the other three suits or pass
column14420:
dealer than may take the bid by naming the suit of throw in the hand. (Some allow for a bid of "Schmeiss" which means to the bidder will take the hand with the turn-up or the hand can be thrown in at the non-bidders discretion)

After bidding
column14421: the dealer deals three more cards to the hand. Then sequences are scored. For this purpose the cards revert back to their numeral rank. A sequence of three scores 20 and a sequence of 4 or more scores 50. tiebreakers are decided by rank. As I will describe later
column14422:
it may make sense not to score in this round and you are not obligated to do so.

Non-dealer leads to first trick. A player must follow suit. If he cannot he must trump if able. If trump is lead he must play a higher trump if able. If he holds the King and Queen of trump he may announce "Bella" on play of the second card and score 50 points. Once again he may choose not to score for this.

After the cards are played
column14423:
both score for the following cards won:

Jass (Jack of Trumps) 20 points
Menel (9 of Trumps) 14 points.
Any Ace 11 points
Any 10 10 points.
Any King 4 points.
Any Queen 3 points.
Any Jack 2 points.
Last Trick 10 points.

If the the high bidder (The one who established trump) scores the highest
column14424:
both sides score what they made. If if opponent scores higher he scores for both totals. This is why the high bidder who realizes he is not going to beat his opponent in this hand may decide not to score or "Sink" points during the hand. 500 points wins the round.

Prior to the onset of Gin Rummy
column14425:
this was the most popular two handed game in the United States. It still holds a loyal following.

Klabberjass remains a popular two handed game in the United States. There are several variations in play and several house rules. It is very popular in New England and especially Hartford

column14506: In 1982 two Italian journalists and historians
column14508:
published a 10-volumes encyclopedia about the history of the modern wars: from American Revolution to latest conflicts (Korea and Vietnam). The name of the work has been Due Secoli di Guerre: “Two Centuries of Wars”

Emilio Ceretti
column14510:
asked to Alex Randolph to invent a boardgame inspired to the encyclopedia.

Being impossible to simulate battles in a period of time from gunpowder to jet fighters
column14511: the result is a sort of an abstract wargame which tries to contain some fixed elements of war: strength vs. mobility
column14513:
and bluff.

The game components are:
-a board with an irregular tessellation
-60 grey pieces with 3 holes each
-120 flags
column14517:
blue)
-the “bluffing bell”

Every player gets 30 flags of his color
column14518:
and places them on 15 grey pieces. A piece with 3 flags has strength 3 and can move one space. A piece with 2 flags has strength 2 and can move up to two spaces… and I think the readers can guess the features of a piece with one flag on it…

Every player enters his units in the map from one side
column14519:
and tries to win being the first to reach the opposite side with one of his units.

The combat system is quite original
column14520: and uses the “bluffing bell”. This is a little device similar to an hand-bell
column14521: containing two little 6-sided dices. Shaking the device makes the dices roll
column14522: and pressing the device on the table causes the dices to be blocked on their result. After the pressing of the “bell”
column14523: the player who is using it can pull it up and see the result
column14524: without showing it to other players. The player can repeat the shaking a number of times equal to the number of his flags involved in the combat
column14525:
until he is satisfied (or wants to feign to be satisfied) by the result: at this point he can declare a result (obviously he can declare a number different from the real one!)
The opponent can now accept the declared result
column14526:
and then try to get and declare an higher number; elsewhere he can try to see the bluff…

Entering the central red square allows the player to aim an “artillery shot” to an enemy unit.

According to Alex Randolph’s ludography compiled by Philippe Evrard
column14527: “Due Secoli di Guerre” has been published only in Italy by Editrice Giochi
column14528:
and there is no report about editions in other countries.

column14537: Piquet is a very old trick-taking card game for 2 players
column14538: reportedly invented by a M. Piquet during the Court of Charles II. It was well established in a form very similar to that used today in 1650 and remained the most popular game in France for many centuries
column14539:
similar to Cribbage in the UK.

A 32-card deck ranking from ace to seven in the four suits is used (known universally as a "Piquet Deck"). A game consists either of 6 deals called a partie (in the Rubicon version) or to 100 points in the "Cents" version. Each player is dealt 12 cards
column14540:
with 8 left as a talon.

Play consists of three distinct stages: (1) the exchange
column14542:
and (3) trick play. Winning requires skill at all three.

In the exchange phase
column14543: players may exchange one to five cards with the talon to improve their hand. Each player's discards are visible to them for the remainder of the game.  The declaration phase involves revealing melds for points (done in a formalized manner so as to reveal some but not all of one's cards). Declarable combinations include: the most cards of one suit; the longest run in a suit; and sets of the same rank
column14545: 4 aces.  The trick phase involves playing out the hand
column14546: with no trump.  Bonuses include taking most tricks
column14548:
and scoring 30 points before the opponent declares.

The small deck combined with the large hands combined with the revealing of each other's cards gives Piquet play a different feel than many card games
column14549: somewhat more akin to a board game.  Part of the strategy of piquet is about controlling information: skillful players carefully determine what they will exchange and declare in order to keep secrets for another phase of the game
column14550:
at the cost of points in another phase.

column15020: The board is a concave wooden block in 3 layers of height. The game pieces have a black and a white side. Each player starts at one end of the board
column15021:
and the goal of the game is to capture or convert the pieces of your opponent.

Tiles can be moved 1 place horizontally
column15023: or diagonally. You can move one level going up
column15024: there is no limitation going down. This means that you can jump on tiles of your opponent if they are at the same height or lower. In this way you convert tiles of your opponent to your own colour. Tiles always move individually: you do not move entire stacks
column15025: just the stack's top tile. When capturing
column15026:
you capture the entire stack.

You can surrender to tiles of your opponent if they are at the same height or higher. Instead of jumping on top of the stack
column15027: you slide underneath it. Your tile is not flipped
column15028: and it keeps its own colour. It is a prisoner of that stack. But if a stack holds a majority of prisoners (more than half)
column15029: there is a revolution. The prisoners become free
column15030:
and the top tile (and all other tiles of the stack) change to the colour of the prisoners.

The game ends if one of the players can make no more moves.

A winner of the 1995 Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société.

column15420:
Two players step into the roles of opposing fleet commanders in this history based recreation of the famous World War II battle between US and Japanese forces. At stake is control of Midway Atoll in the Central Pacific. The US player must risk his navy's three carriers to try to keep it; the Japanese player must risk his four carriers to try to take it.

The atoll and the aircraft carriers are each represented by their own card. Players throw reconnaissance cards to find and fix the enemy's location
column15421: then play other cards representing attacking squadrons. Some find their targets
column15422:
others don't. Sometimes the enemy shows up over your fleet without warning. Everything often hinges - literally and figuratively - on the timely throw of one card.

Lightning Game Series

column15432: This two-player card game recreates the drama of the day Allied soldiers went ashore in occupied France
column15433: 6 June 1944. Each of the historic landing beaches - Gold
column15436: Omaha and Utah - is represented by its own card
column15437:
as are the defending German divisions and attacking Allied units. The Allied player must marshal his resources to gain and secure control of every beach by day's end: one run-through of the 110-card deck.

The tension in the game increases with each card thrown
column15438: like the build up in a close baseball game. At first it seems the Allies have resources to meet every crisis across the beachheads
column15439: but if a key airborne division gets scattered across the countryside
column15440: allowing a counterattacking panzer division to slip through the perimeter
column15441: everything can change instantly. And an Allied unit committed to one beach
column15442: where you might find the defense isn't as strong as you thought
column15443: can't be called back in time to rush to the true danger zone. Both players must constantly be thinking ahead
column15444:
looking for ways to best utilize their cards several throws down the line.

Lightning Game Series

strategic bombing and the atomic bomb.

simulates the American Civil War from the opening shots at Fort Sumter to Lee's surrender at Appomattox.

The game can be played as a huge campaign using all three maps and simulating the entire war from beginning to end. That requires hundreds of man-hours.

the type with the majority points is the one ejected.

Players play one card from their hand and draw from the row

It took a while to get the hang of the game and it's an odd mix of switching tactics

column15693:
Background:

This game is a forerunner of many "dice" games and the game younger children play today which is known as Jacks. The game was "old" by the time it was played in Ancient Rome
column15694: since it had been played in Greece and other parts of the ancient world before it found its way to Rome. The game has many counterparts throughout the Middle East and Asia. Some historians indicate that the game may have had its origins in some religious rite
column15695:
while others believe the game was always just a gambling game.

Knucklebones are the dried ankle bones of sheep. They have 4 different sides - one flat
column15698: and one sinuous side. Values were assigned to each side. In ancient times
column15699: adults as well as children played Knucklebones. The Greeks and the Romans modified the equipment and play of this gambling game
column15700:
eventually passing on to us six sided cubed dice rather than the four sided Astragali.

Game play:
The game is played with two or more bones. One player tosses the bones in the air and either catches them on the back of the hand
column15701: or lets them fall to the ground. As in dice games
column15702:
assigned values determine the outcome of each toss.

Reimplemented by Oss

An ingenious cross between Risk and Scrabble Junior. From the instructions:

"Worldmaster: A game of strategy for two or four players [in partnerships]. Build a CONNECTED EMPIRE
column15724:
covering at least half the letters of each of its countries with letters of your colour -- Red or Blue. Numbered circles tell you how many letters you need to cover."

The board consists of a Risk-like simplified map of the world. Countries are labelled like words on a Scrabble Junior board; each letter is enclosed in a box the size of a Scrabble tile. Each country also has a numbered circle indicating half the length of the country’s name (rounded up; two circles for countries whose names have an even number of letters). Each player (or partnership) receives a bag of letter tiles
column15725:
which contains just enough to cover all the letters on the map.

High-speed rules summary from the instructions:

RULE 1: In each turn place one or more letters
column15727: or store up all of them. End the turn by drawing four
column15728:
always.

RULE 2: Earn country "flags" -- coloured markers -- once you’ve covered as many letters as the circles show. (Only one flag of your colour in any country! The enemy may share countries with two circles
column15729:
if you don’t prevent this.)

RULE 3: Flags on EIGHT connected countries wins -- or ELEVEN in games with the Airports rule. (Two extra letters earn an "airport ring" over the flag. Groups connect by air when each group has an airport.)

thereby sending the OOP into the air and (you hope) into the CAN.

Blue and Red OOPS

CAN.
Instruction Sheet

column15761:
[translated from the box]

Diam is a game of strategy for 2
column15763:
or 4 players. The simplicity of the rules and the depth of play will satisfy players of all strengths and all ages.

The goal of the game: to place 2 pawns of identical color at the same height on 2 diametrically opposed spaces.

The objective is very clear
column15764:
and you constantly feel you're close to winning. Victory is within your grasp!

But beware
column15765: this simplicity is misleading.  With each move
column15766: your opponent can discern your intentions and launch a counter-attack!  You'll need solid nerves.  Stay focused
column15768:
move your colors with accuracy and you will become the master of Diam!

How to play?

In the beginning
column15769:
each player has a reserve of 8 pawns: 4 red pawns and 4 orange pawns for player 1: 4 maroon pawns and 4 black pawns for player 2.

In a turn
column15770:
each player can:

either place a pawn from the player's reserve onto an empty space or onto a pawn already on the board
column15771:
or move one of the player's pawns already placed on the board to an adjacent space.


With 3 players:
This alternative is played has 2 against 1. The basic rules are identical to the rules for 4 players; the player who is alone having 2 colors
column15772:
however.

With 4 players:
This alternative is played by teams of 2. Each player has his own color and the players play in turn.

The basic rules are identical to the rules for 2 players
column15773:
the following constraint is added:

a player cannot place a pawn from his partner's reserve.
a player can
column15775:
move his pawns or his partner's pawns already on the board.


A winner of the 1998 Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société.

column15929: using a board which represents Greater Manchester (England)
column15930:
in as much as each of the spaces is named after a Greater Manchester place name and the positions are approximately related to geography. Wigan borough place names have been excluded presumably because it upsets the symmetry of the board.
As well as the board
column15932:
different colour skittle pieces. Some of the games use a die and/or cards.
The rules to each game are brief (one A5 sheet or less) and simple. They have varying degrees of tactical scope. Some are race games but most are abstract strategies. The main appeal is the use of local names
column15933:
assuming that the player is 'local'.

Some of the games use a random element in the piece set up (by drawing place name cards)

The limits in the number of players for each game seems to be more a function of the pieces issued rather than game balance. There would seem to be scope for adding players if extra pieces were drafted in from another game.

ANCOATS (2-6 players) is a movement game. Ability to move depends on the colour of the card drawn
column15937:
the colour of the space the piece is on and the colour it is moving to. The winner is the first player to land on the three places determined by a random selection of three cards at the start of the game.

BURNAGE (2-6 players) a movement game collecting cards at each space visited
column15938:
or challenging other players for the cards they have collected. The winner being the first to collect a predetermined number of cards.

In OFFERTON (2 players) the start location of pieces is randomised by cards. After that
column15939:
distance of movement is determined by the points on each space. The winner is the fist player to get their six counters in a contiguous line.

PRESTOLEE (2-5 players) is a die movement game. The winner is the first player to move to all 16 spaces of the player's colour
column15940:
collecting a card at each location space.

RUSHOLME (2-6 players) has randomized set up
column15941:
but movement is then dictated by the points and colours of each space. The winner is the first to collect a specified number of counters distributed around the board.

SEEDLEY (2-4 players) is a card game which uses the board for reference. A player can only pick up a place name card off the discard pile
column15942:
if they are discarding an adjacent place name.

WERNETH (2 players) Players take it in turns to place a counter on the board
column15943: until there are 12 in total.  They then place their coloured skittle on the board.  They then take it in turns to move the their skittle according to the points on the space
column15944: restrictions on combinations of the colour of the current space
column15945: the space it is moving to
column15947:
or the presence of a counter or opponent's skittle. The loser is the first player who cannot make a legal move on their turn.

column16014: On a square board players take turns placing cubes (sarsens) which may be played on the ground or on any piece of your color
column16015:
and (3x1) rectangles (lintels) which can be placed in such a way that they are supported at both ends and are supported by exactly two blocks of your color and optionally one block of the opponent's color. The simplest configuration therefore resembles a mini Stone Henge (hence the name).

The space in between can be empty or occupied by a piece of either color.

One player is attempting to connect the top and bottom of the board and the other player the left and right edges. Connectivity is judged as seen from above so that higher pieces can cut the connection of lower ones. Or to quote the rules:

Two sects of Druids want to build a monument on the same sacred site
column16016: however there is some conflict. The followers of Horizontus believe that the monument should track the sun from the East horizon to the West horizon to worship the passing days
column16017:
while the followers of Verticalus believe that the monument should track the sun from the North to the South to worship the passing seasons.

The game has several variants including a version played on a hex grid (also playable by three) and both the hexagonal and square versions have a "Druid's Walk" variation in which an additional piece represents a druid out for a stroll.

play by email or play by web)

column16060: The aim of the game is to form equilateral triangles using pegs of the same color.  The players take turns and place one peg each turn.  In doing so it doesn’t matter which color peg is placed on the board.  If the player is unable to form a triangle
column16061: he then tries to prevent the other from forming an equilateral triangle by using the joker (the red peg).  The winner is the player who places the last peg of a triangle.  If no player is able to make a triangle

column16071: the game of Nim is a two-player game of perfect information in which there are some number of rows or "heaps" of objects
column16072: and a legal move consists of removing any number of objects from a single heap. (For a non-trivial game
column16073: we should start with at least three heaps.) In "standard play"
column16074: the player who cannot make a move on his turn (because no objects remain) is the loser. A very general and far-reaching theory of such games is developed in Berlekamp
column16076:
and Guy's Winning Ways for Your Mathematical Plays.

In the commercial version pictured
column16080: or 4 pegs together in a row. It would appear from the picture that "rows" can run in any direction
column16081: which means that the "heaps" intersect. This is not what most people know as Nim. Also
column16083: in this version the loser is the player who has to remove the last peg. This is so-called "misere play"
column16084:
rather than the standard winning condition. Many combinatorial games allow misère play as a variation.

Nim is solved
column16085: which means that from any initial configuration
column16086: one can readily determine whether the next player or the previous player has a winning strategy
column16087: and identify a good next move in the former case. For Nim
column16088: this can be determined surprisingly readily no matter the size of the heaps
column16089:
but you're not going to get the secret from me.

As most who would be interested in Nim know the solution
column16090: there isn't much of a game here. But Nim plays a central role in the theory of combinatorial games
column16091: as any two-player finite impartial game is in some sense Nim in disguise: any position in such a game corresponds to a unique Nim-heap
column16092: and one can play the disguised game perfectly by making the moves that correspond to winning moves in Nim. Sprouts is one example. This however does not mean that Sprouts itself is solved
column16093:
as the "disguise" is only partially revealed.

column16143:
Box blurb says:
Deep Space Mission Briefing. Captain's Log Stardate 30.26.5. The Enterprise is menaced by a deadly Klingon War Ship. Only Zithium and Beton Crystals from the Planet of Fire and the Ice Planet can destroy it.
Your Mission. Bring back both Crystals and plant them in the War Ship Bridge. Look out for the Blurg
column16144: the Spider and the Klingons.  Also look Out For Refuge Squares
column16147:
Alarms and the Baroom Card!!

This Star Trek Game is a board game for two to six players produced in 1975 by Palitoy for the UK game market. This game is TOS-based
column16148: and was advertised as "Taken from the popular BBC TV Series Star Trek". Much of the game's artwork seems to have been done by – or at least
column16149: influenced by – the artists who worked on the Gold Key Star Trek comic. Players play crewmembers of the Enterprise assigned to obtain alien crystals from two planets that can be used to destroy a nearby Klingon warship
column16150:
while avoiding capture by either the Klingons or the indigenous creatures on either planet.

Gameplay: The object of the game is to land on two planets – the "Planet of Fire" and the "Ice Planet" – to retrieve a sample of "Zithium" and "Beton" (respectively) to use against the Klingons and destroy their ship.
As crewmembers of the Enterprise
column16151: you have been assigned to obtain a crystal of each substance from their respective plantes
column16152:
while avoiding a giant alien spider (which protects the crystals on the Planet of Fire) and an amorphous blob called a Blurg (who protects the crystals on the Ice Planet).

Each player starts in the Enterprise transporter room and tries to roll the number of the transporter pad to which they are assigned to "beam down" to one of the planets. (If they cannot do this within three rolls
column16153: they "beam down" automatically.) The player then traverses the game path on the planet to try and reach the cavern containing the crystals at the path's end. Players can obtain help from Kirk or Spock by landing on the space with their picture. They can also be captured if landed on by either creature or a Klingon (spaces on the path allow either the creatures to move or the Klingons to beam down to the planets)
column16154: but by the player having Kirk and/or Spock with them
column16155:
the player can have their "senior officer" "stun" their attacker and continue play.

Once a player obtains the crystal from one planet
column16156: they return to the Enterprise and go through "decontamination" (moving along the red and white path near the transporter room). They then return to the transporter (via the yellow and green path) and attempt to "beam down" to the other planet and get the second crystal. They then return to the Enterprise and undergo "decontamination" again before proceeding to the Enterprise's "airlock" and attempting to board the Klingon ship. From their
column16157: the player must enter the Klingon bridge
column16159: and beam back to the Enterprise and undergo "decontamination" a third time before landing on the "Detonator" space and playing the "Baroom" card on the Klingon ship
column16160:
thus destroying it and winning the game.

Source: Memory Alpha Wiki

column16496: ASG Baseball is a tabletop baseball simulation which uses individual batter and pitcher cards and dice to accurately recreate games between Major League Baseball teams. The game's distinctivie design feature is that batter-pitcher encounters are resolved by rolling the dice and consulting the pitcher's card. In some cases the outcome of the play is determined directly from the pitcher's card. In other cases the pitcher's card may direct you to a specific column (one of six) on the batter's card for the play result. The columns on the batter's card are organized to reflect the batter's normal
column16498:
and below normal batting average and slugging percentage. Advocates of the game argue that dominant pitchers are more realistically simulated by this play design in that they exert more control over the outcome of each at bat than is the case for better-known baseball boardgames such as APBA and Strat-O-Matic.

ASG also includes clutch hitting
column16507:
stamina and unusual plays.

column16767:
From the rules:

Planetaire is a game of planetary war. From the surface
column16772:
killer satellites and beam tanks.

Description:

Planetaire is an abstract strategy game played on a board of four concentric circular tracks (orbits). A player takes one action on a turn; an action can be moving a piece
column16774:
or loading or unloading fighters (which can be carried by motherships).

The different pieces move and attack differently. Fighters move two spaces a turn and can only attack adjacent pieces. Motherships can move one space or jump into hyperspace from the outer orbit (allowing them to re-enter any space in the outer orbit on a later turn)
column16775:
and they have beam weapons which can attack pieces two or three spaces away. Beam tanks and killer satellites also have beam weapons; beam tanks can only move around the inner orbit and satellites can only jump into hyperspace.

The object of the game is to remove all opposing pieces from the inner orbit.

From the rules:

Dioxoid is a game of chain reactions. Inside an oxygen molecule
column16784: two players bounce their electrons against each other to surround the opponent's nucleus. A single action may cause a reaction that advances or disrupts every electron
column16785:
changing the entire game.

Description:

Dioxoid is an abstract strategy game. Each player has eight identical pieces which represent electrons. These move one space at a time. When an electron moves adjacent to any other electron
column16786: the non-moving electron is repelled and must move away; if it cannot
column16787: the moving electron moves away. The repelled electrons may cause others to move
column16788:
etc. The object is to get all of one's own electrons into the opponent's starting spaces.

or diagonal rows of three or more dots of the same color to score the highest possible points.

column16810: a game of prospecting somewhere in the 19th-century American West (the map is not of a real area
column16811:
although the place names are similar to some found in Montana).

The map is divided into numerous small areas which the players claim and then attempt to find something in. Every area has a potential number which indicates how likely it is to find something (fertile soil
column16815: of gold) there.  Each number has an associated set of outcomes for a 2-dice roll
column16816: which in addition to finding something include action cards from the deck
column16819: and monetary penalties.  Areas not likely to produce soil
column16821:
or minerals are more likely to provide cards or income.

Once you find something
column16822: you get paid for the claim and that area is done with.  Some things pay better than others
column16823: with gold of course paying the most
column16824: but this is offset by the fact that making the same strike in an adjacent area will pay double (and a third will double again
column16826:
and the less valuable items are easier to find.

Action cards can be used to rob or tax other players
column16829:
etc. The "take that" effect is presumably somewhat reduced by the small hand size (2 in a 4-player game).

The attention to usability in the components is somewhat unusual for a self-published game of this vintage. Each player gets a "calculator" which lets you slide a cardboard strip up and down to get the dice-rolling chart for each claim potential (and robbery attempt) individually
column16830: instead of having to look it up in a larger chart.  In addition
column16831: each calculator has on it a probability table which shows the total percent chance of each possible outcome for each claim potential
column16832:
and a list of all the action cards and their uses.

column16843: Hidden Empires is a print-and-play game for 2 to 6 players where each player assumes the role of an ant colony.  Players deploy worker ants on an abstracted hex-area map to look for and forage food.  Colonies use food to produce more workers to produce more food
column16844:
etc. Eventually colonies grow large enough to produce reproductive male and female ants. Players score points for each reproductive ant released during a nuptial flight.

A deck of cards provide environmental events and different genetic traits for the various ant species. Conflict between colonies is possible but is not the primary focus of the game. All events
column16846:
and general game play are based on the natural history of actual ant species.

As of 2012 a new version
column16860:
A detailed tactical simulation of the Battle of Antietam. Uses James Murphy's Battles of the War of the Rebellion rule set.

Published in 1978
column16861: 100yds/hex; 15 min./turn. 21 different types of terrain on the TEC. Morale ratings from 11-66. 12 point unit facing and flexible extended line options.  As a result of a morale check a unit can take cover
column16864: or rout move. Simple but effective command and control rules:  the further a unit from its HQ
column16865: the lower its movement allowance.  A unit moving more than half its MA loses firepower during the enemy portion of the turn; if it moves more than its printed allowance (fatigue rules)
column16866: it can't fire during the enemy portion of the turn.  The game is so detailed
column16867: it includes stubble markers for use when Miller's Cornfield is mowed down by fire
column16868:
and has a beehive rule for use if Mr. Roulette's beehives are smashed by artillery fire.

Arthur Mitchell and David Buchbinder.

column16980: The object of the game is to find your opponent's secret word. Each player chooses a five letter word and writes it down so the other cannot see it. The word should be in the dictionary and can include letters that repeat. One player now announces a test word and the second player reveals how many letters in that word are the same as the letters in his secret word. Such a letter is called a jot and the first player marks down how many jots that word contained. Players take turns guessing and use the information (number of jots) they have gathered to guess the opponents secret word.

column17029: Empire of the Sun: The Pacific War 1941-1945
column17040:
(from GMT website:)

Empire of the Sun (EotS) is Mark Herman's third card driven design since he introduced the system to the hobby in We The People. EotS is a strategic level look at the entire War in the Pacific from the attack on Pearl Harbor until the surrender of Japan. EotS is the first card driven game (CDG) to move the system closer to a classic hexagon wargame
column17041: while retaining all of the tension and uncertainty people have come to expect from a CDG. Players are cast in the role of MacArthur
column17044:
and Mountbatten as you direct your forces across the breadth of the globe from India to Hawaii and from Alaska to Australia. This is represented on a single map based on a 1942 equal area projection of the entire theater of conflict.

As in other games using the CDG system
column17045:
players try to maximize the impact of their cards even as they hide their intentions and traps from their opponent. The player is faced with a wide set of clear strategic choices. The focus of EotS is on directing major offensive axes of advance. The Japanese early in the game are challenged to achieve their historical expansion as Allied forces battle the clock to react with their in-place forces trying to achieve maximum damage to the hard-to-replace Japanese veteran units.

Combat in EotS is based on successfully bringing superior combined land
column17047: and sea forces to bear in a two-tiered combat system. The first tier is the resolution of air-naval combat
column17048:
the second tier covers ground combat. The culmination of both tiers results in one side prevailing in battle.

The key variable in determining strategic victory is the level of U.S. political will. The Japanese win the game by forcing the U.S. into a negotiated peace
column17049: which was not achieved historically. The Japanese achieve this by knocking countries like India
column17051: and Australia out of the war
column17052: while inflicting massive casualties on the United States. The delivery of the A-bomb on its historical schedule is not a guarantee
column17053:
often necessitating Operation Olympic and the invasion of Japan. It is often in its darkest hour that the Japanese find victory in EotS.
EotS scenarios were designed with the busy enthusiast
column17055: and competitive tournament player in mind. EotS was designed to be played n yearly scenarios (1942
column17057: and 1944) of three turns each that play in under two hours. If you are a fan of CDG's
column17058: EotS takes the genre into a familiar
column17059: but new direction. If you are a fan of classic hexagon wargames
column17060: this game has all of the features that brought you to this hobby in the first place
column17061: but with a new level of excitement and replayability. The game is comprehensive
column17062:
but easy to learn.

TIME SCALE: 4 months per turn
MAP SCALE: 150 miles per hex
UNIT SCALE: Brigade
column17065:
and Army

DESIGNER: Mark Herman
DEVELOPER: Stephen Newberg
MAP & CARD ART: Mark Simonitch
COUNTER ART: Mark Simonitch
column17067:
& Rodger B. MacGowan


(from the designer:)

Empire of the Sun (EOTS)
column17068: uses a variant of my card driven system. The game has one map that covers the Pacific Theater of operations from India to Hawaii
column17069: and from the Aleutians to Australia. EOTS is the first card driven game to use hexes
column17070: which facilitates calculating movement and aircraft ranges. Each game turn covers 4 months (three turns per year) with a special December 41 (special two card) game turn
column17071:
for a total of 12 game turns for the campaign.

The game is at the strategic level using naval units built around a capital ship class (e.g.
column17075: air units at the Air Force/ Air Flotilla/ Air Division level
column17076:
and most ground units are Corps/ Armies although there are a host of specialized units at the division and below level. The game has 165 cards divided into an Allied and a Japanese deck.

The game uses a two tiered combat system with air-naval combat preceding ground combat. The system has players roll for combat efficiency
column17077: which is a strength multiplier from .5 to 2. This value multiplied by the unit strengths is the number of hits the enemy takes in combat
column17078:
with some special conditions based on number of CVs present and the like.

As far as game play is concerned
column17079: China is abstracted using a track whereby the play of certain events and Chinese offensives puts pressure on the Allies to support this theater with resources or see it fall and hurt Allied morale. This is balanced against the fact that Japanese land replacements come from this theater
column17080: so the more they draw it down for conflict in other locations
column17081:
the more likely China will survive.

Northern India and Burma are active theaters of operation where the majority of the continuous ground warfare in the game occurs. If the Japanese can successfully occupy Northern India
column17082:
they can drive this nation and its Commonwealth units out of the war.

Australia can also be knocked out of the war
column17083:
although it is hard to keep it out permanently.

Then of course there is the famous island campaigns with the US driving across the Pacific to knock Japan out of the war.

column17292: in which the outlaw tries to chase down and rob the stagecoach.  The stagecoach moves one or two spaces (determined by a die roll) along a fixed path toward East City.  The outlaw moves one or two spaces forward or backward
column17293: and may utilize the shortcuts.  Once the outlaw ends a move on the same space as the stagecoach
column17294: a gunfight occurs.  The gunfight consists of the outlaw winning three out of three rounds of "Who can roll a higher number on the die?" - re-rolling in the event of a tie.  If the stagecoach wins the gunfight
column17295:
it escapes with a free move.



Shark Attack sends 2-4 players diving for treasure in slightly shark-infested waters. On your turn
column17298: generally toward the treasure.  You may not swim through other pawns.  If you start your turn in the shark attack zone
column17300: then you will also roll and move the shark.  The shark may swim through other pawns
column17301: but if it ends its movement on a player's pawn
column17302: that pawn goes back to the boat and starts over.  The goal is not only to get past the shark to reach the treasure
column17303:
but also return through the shark's waters to the boat thereafter.



Alien Invaders From Space is a 1-player roll-and-move with a die-driven squad of aliens hunting you along the path. A die roll indicates which 3-4 of six rooms are occupied by aliens. For your attempted escape
column17305: you roll a die.  On an even roll
column17306: you move that many spaces; odd
column17307: the alien in the current room (if any) moves that many spaces
column17308: eventually getting into your path and threatening you.  One exception:  If you roll a 1
column17310:
and you roll again to determine their new three or four starting rooms. You simply try to reach your "rocket ship to Earth" without a turn ending you and an alien on the same space.

column17678:
A traditional two-player Japanese card game played with the beautiful Hanafuda (literally 'Flower card') deck.

Setup: the cards are all shuffled
column17679: and one card is randomly revealed: the player whom the birthday month is closer to the revealed card month is the first player and thus the dealer. The cards are shuffled again and handed out
column17682:
as for the face-up talon in the middle of the table.

Turn: Then each player proceeds as so: firstly
column17683: he discards a card face up on the table from his hand. If that card matches another card on the table (matching months)
column17684: the player then wins both cards which he puts in his face-up collection
column17685: in front of him. The collection is always displayed in 4 columns
column17688: Animals and Specials. If it doesn't match anything
column17689: the discarded card stays on the table. Secondly
column17691: the player then draws the first card from the face down deck
column17692: and proceeds the same way: if it doesn't match any card
column17693: the drawn card stays on the table
column17694: but if it does match a card
column17695:
the player wins both cards which he adds to his collection. Then the other player takes his turn.

Turn's End: At the end of a player's turn
column17697: he can stop the current month (inning) by stating his Yakus
column17698: then the points are scored and the next month begins. However
column17699: if he wishes to continue in order to increase his score for this month
column17700: he says "Koi-Koi" and the other player takes his turn. If later on during the game
column17701: the player who said Koi-Koi wins another Yaku OR increases his previous Yakus
column17702: he can then again stop the game or say Koi-Koi
column17703: as many times as he wants. But if a player gets a Yaku in a game where his opponent already said Koi-Koi
column17704: then he gets the right either to say Koi-Koi too
column17705: or to stop the game and receive his points
column17706:
thus leading his opponent to get no points at all this month.

End: Since each player has 8 cards in his hand
column17707: a month (inning) can at worse last 16 turns. In case of a game where one (or both) player(s) said Koi-Koi and no more Yakus have been added or increased before the month ends
column17708: then only the last player who said Koi-Koi scores his points as usual. The winner of a month becomes the dealer for the next month
column17709:
or stays the same if there was not any winner.

Each Yaku can add itself to the others. Here are the Yakus:

Basic Yakus

10 Flowers / Kasu : 1 point (Each additional Flower adds 1 point)
5 Ribbons / Tanzaku : 1 point (Each additional Ribbon adds 1 point)
3 Purple Ribbons (blue) / Aotan : 5 points
3 Ribbons with Poems (red) / Akatan : 5 points
5 Animals / Tane : 1 Point (Each additional Animal adds 1 point)
Doe + Boar + Butterflies / Ino Shika Chô : 5 Points
3 Specials without the Rain Man / Sankô : 5 Points
4 Specials with the Rain Man / Ameshikô : 6 points
4 Special without the Rain Man / Shikô : 8 Points
5 Specials : Gokô : 10 points

Special Yakus

The Moon + The Sake Cup / Tsukizake : 5 points (Bonus Yaku
column17710:
only in addition to at least another normal Yaku)
The Cherry Curtain + The Sake Cup / Hanamizake : 5 points (Bonus Yaku
column17711:
only in addition to at least another normal Yaku)
The Iris Flower is a "Joker" card: it can either be counted as an Animal
column17712:
or as Flower to form a Kasu (but not both).
The 4 Cards of the current Month / TsukiFuda : 5 points
No Yakus / OyaKen : 1 point

The game ends when one player reaches 50 points. In some variants
column17713: at the end of a month
column17714: the points scored by a player are subtracted from his opponent's score. In some variants
column17715:
the player with the most points at the end of the year (December) wins the game.

The player may than turn around as many cards in a row as allowed by the die - the cards remain face up till the end of the game. Block wargame.

The campaigns for Texas Independence were much more than just the Alamo. Texas Glory includes the preliminary 1835 clashes when the Texans under Austin expelled the Mexican garrison from San Antonio de Bejar. It then covers Santa Anna's 1836 surprise late winter campaign that began with his recapture of the Alamo
column18020: but ended with Texan victory at the Battle of San Jacinto on April 21
column18021:
1836.

This fast-playing game reflects the balanced struggle between the Mexicans and the Texans. Sam Houston must delay superior Mexican forces until he can gather enough troops to risk a battle. The Mexicans must sweep across Texas with utmost speed because time and supply are their enemies. The significant role of "American Volunteers" in the eventual outcome becomes clear.

Zenith – A crossword game.

That’s Incredible! – A memory game that uses the colors on the cards.
Castaways – The players use the cards dealt to them to calculate a target number determined by the dealer.
Sequence 26 – A memory game that uses the letters on the cards.
Corner Bank – Players score for remembering combinations of colors.
Preposterous – Players score for remembering sequences of numbers.
Unravel – The dealer selects a secret combination of colors and the other player must deduce the combination by making guesses.
Shootout – The colors have rank and the player who reveals the highest ranked card during a round wins all cards of all the other players.

column18405: Thorns is a variant on the game Hex. The gameboard is made up of "Thorns"
column18406:
which are squares with triangles on each side. The squares and triangles are arranged in a grid.

Players alternate turns. Each turn
column18407:
a player marks one of the squares with their symbol (X or O) and draws a line through the square and into two of the triangles on opposite sides. This creates a "thorn". The players are attempting to create a continuous path of thorns from one side of the board to another. Thorns are considered touching if they touch or if their triangles overlap

The first player to create a continuous path from one side of the board to the other is the winner.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

Nab consists of 15 circles arranged in a triangular pattern. The players take turns drawing lines through from 1 to 5 circles. All of the circles in the line must be in a straight line with each other and cannot have been marked through previously. The player who is forced to draw the line through the last unmarked circle loses.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

column18426:
Hedron is played on a board representing an opened dodecahedron (12 sided surface) which forms 12 five-sided areas. (the "outside" of the figure is the 12th area). The players take turns placing an "X" or an "O" on one of the lines of the figure. Whoever puts marks on three or more sides of an area controls that area and gets the points for that area (printed inside). Whoever puts marks on three or more of the border sides gets the points for the "12th" area. The player with the most points wins.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.
column18435: Plasm is played on a grid of pentagons. Scattered among the pentagons are a series of two
column18436:
three and five pointed shapes which are shaded.

The players take turns making either an "X" or an "O" in the pentagons. Their first move can be anywhere
column18437:
but subsequent moves must be connected to a pentagon which they have already claimed.

Points are scored by surrounding the shaded areas. The player who claims the last pentagon surrounding the shaded area claims it by putting their mark inside the area. Shaded areas are scored by the number of points they have.

Play continues until all of the shaded areas have been claimed. The player with the highest point total wins.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

Players continue to alternate moves until all shaded squares have been captured. The player capturing the most shaded squares is the winner.

Part of the 3M Paper Games Series.

column18499: "Go-Moku" (Japanese - also spelled "Gomoku") or "wuziqi" (Chinese) is a very old game played with a Go set. The game can also be played on a sheet of graph paper using X's and O's. It is similar in idea to tic-tac-toe
column18500:
but far greater in scale and complexity. The name means "five points."

It is debated whether this game originated in China or Japan
column18501:
with more evidence pointing to the former.

The object is to get five stones in a row. The game is played on a 19x19 board (such as the board used in Go)
column18502: creating a large and open field to complete this objective. The game can also be played on a smaller board
column18503:
such as the popular 15x15 option.

If played perfectly
column18504: Black (who goes first) can always win the game. Even before this was proven
column18505:
the game was recognized to be easier for Black. This problem is solved in Renju. which is often seen as the adult contemporary to the kids' Go-Moku.

""
column18514: Renju is the adult/tournament version of the Japanese game Go-Moku.  Renju is played on a 15x15 Go board
column18515:
with Go pieces.

The goal is the same: to get five stones in a row. Renju has evolved rules to balance the game however: Go-Moku heavily favors the first player.

Renju counters this with two important rules:


Setup: one player places two black stones and one white stone on the board. The other player chooses which side to play. White places one stone
column18516: then Black places two more stones.  White removes one of these last two Black stones
column18517:
then the game proceeds normally.
Restrictions: Black may not create a three-three or four-four. (That is
column18518: a move that creates two open-ended threes at once
column18519: or two fours at once.)  Black may not create an "overline" - six or more stones in a row.  White is NOT thus restricted
column18520: and can win by any of those moves
column18521:
OR by forcing Black to make such a move to block White.


Renju lacks the depth of Go
column18522: but the strategies are far easier to understand
column18523:
and mere mortals can become quite good at it.

Similar to:

5ive Straight
Take 5
5 in a Row
Go-Moku
Pente

column18594: While the rules call this a wargame
column18595:
it is highly abstract and more of a family game.

The system is an interesting attempt at representing the general flow of a given battle with very simple rules. The board consists of a (very sketchy) schematic of the battle area overlaid with arrows indicating the troop movements
column18596:
much as one might see on a diagram of a battle.

The arrows are divided into spaces - on a turn
column18597: a player rolls a die and moves a piece (infantry or cavalry - the artillery does not move) along the appropriate arrow (which arrow or arrows it can use depends on where it starts).  Landing on certain spaces may let you advance further
column18598: or may destroy the piece (there are a number of the latter spaces on the Light Brigade's paths).  Getting to the end of an arrow destroys an enemy piece
column18600:
but sometimes has other effects on the opponent.

There are special rules for each group indicating what its orders are or what it actually did in the battle
column18601: more or less (some can traverse the arrows more than once
column18602:
etc.).

While the box says that either 2 or 4 people can play
column18603: there is no provision in the rules for more than 2
column18604:
and no obvious way to accommodate this.

Greensmith designed a similar game for Palitoy on the battle of Waterloo.

column18885:
Theme
Brave knights are gathering to plan their honourable endeavours and to find out who will be the bravest Paladin facing the most honourable missiona.

Goal
To collect as many honour points as possible by winning mission cards.

Setup
Each player gets 5 player tokens of one colour.

The 18 mission cards are sorted into two stacks
column18886: according to their honour point values (1-6). Each stack is shuffled separately
column18887: then the stack with the lower value mission cards (queen's deck
column18888: values 1-3) is placed on top of the other (king's deck
column18889:
values 4-6).

Mission cards equal to the number of players are laid out
column18890:
face up.

The card dealer shuffles the 42 paladin cards and hands out 4-6 (depending on the number of players) cards to each player. Paladin cards have values from 0-9.

Game play
Each player
column18892: puts one of his/her paladin cards next to one of the mission cards
column18894: and marks it with one of his/her player tokens. This paladin is called the leading paladin. When each mission card has a leading paladin
column18895:
players continue playing cards clockwise until each player has placed a card beside each mission.
Before placing a card
column18896:
players may look at one of the cards another player has already placed. Each player can only play one paladin per mission.
When each player has only one card left
column18898:
starting with the first mission and the first card that was placed there. Each player has the following options:

Beat the leading paladin if your card has a higher value (or in case they are equal
column18899:
if it is a red number).
Take the face-down paladin card back on your hand.
Discard the face-down paladin card.


This continues until all cards at the first mission have been dealt with. The player whose card is the last to stay wins the mission and places it
column18900: together with the winning paladin card
column18901:
in front of him/herself. The same is done for the other mission cards.

The player with the fewest honour points is the dealer of the next round and hands out paladin cards until everyone has the same number of cards as in the first round. The dealer then lays out new mission cards and determines a start player.

The game ends when there are not enough mission cards left for another round. Each player counts the honour points from the missions he/she won and adds bonus points for all paladin cards with red numbers that the/she has in front of him/herself. The player with the most points wins the game.

column19346: Australia was a penal colony of the British Empire for decades. Only the far southeastern section had mountains and rivers and fertile land; when gold was discovered there in 1851
column19347:
people rushed to this empty land in huge numbers.

Commercial development boomed and the first railway was completed in 1854.

With the population explosion came huge sheep ranches
column19351:
ships and other manufactures.

An expanding railway network quickly grew in the three states shown on the game board.

Many of Australia's early railways were built by the individual state governments to further the development of the boom. Australia did not become a single Federal entity until 1901; the game covers the development of Australia's Railways from 1850-1900.

Australian Railways is part of the Early Railways Series.

column19366:
Strange things are happening over at the Smithville Cemetery - it seem like the residents there are unhappy about their surroundings and looking to move uptown! It's up to a small band of brave heroes to put the Zombies in their place - or become and undead appetizer.

Zombie Hunt is a boardgame for 2 to 4 players. There are two sides in the game
column19367: but each side can be run by more than one player. The object for the Zombie player(s) is to tunnel out of their graves and overwhelm the Human defenders before the sun comes up. The Humans player(s) must stem the Zombie tide and hold on - time is on the Human's side
column19368:
but there are an awful lot of Zombies...

Published in TSRs Comics Module RIP #2.

column19392: The Cossacks Are Coming!: The Tannenberg Campaign August and September
column19401:
(from Oregon Consim Games website:)

The Cossacks Are Coming! (2nd Edition) is an extensively researched historical model of the Russian invasion of Germany in August and September of 1914. The design is a revision of the original The Cossacks are Coming! (People’s War Games 1982). Based on the 3rd edition Death of Empires rules system the five scenarios include an introductory scenario
column19403:
Tannenberg and First Masurian) and a campaign game scenario.

Game Scale:

Units: Primarily brigade/divisional 1000 to 1500 men per strength point for infantry
column19404: 450 to 900 men per strength point of cavalry
column19405:
2 to 3 batteries per strength point of artillery.
Time: Weekly turns composed of two to three impulses.
Map: 5 miles per hex.


Contents:

840 two sided die cut counters
One 22" x 34" Map
Standard and Exclusive Rule Booklets
4 Player Aid Charts
6 Strategic and Army Charts
8 Campaign Scenario Set-up Charts
Two 6-sided dice

column19445: Limits: Captain John's Sportfishing Tournament Game
column19448:
From the publisher:

" " Your fishing club has decided to have a National Fishing Tournament with various groups within the club competing against each other.
You will venture to Lake Erie
column19451: and Lake Temagami to fish for Walleye
column19456: which includes the likes of Dennis
column19458:
Bob and Captain John will be competing with the other groups.
In the Imaginary Sense all table players will be fishing together as one group as you pay and collect from each other for various mishaps and team rule infractions which occur during the trip.
In the Real Sense your own group -you- will be attempting to be the first to "Limit Out" in all four sportfish categories and return home to collect accumulated "Limits Pool" prize money along with as many other tournament prizes you can capture. "

" The mishaps are real-life experiences and frequent.
Catching Sheepshead
column19461:
will count against your performance.
The prize categories are proportioned to give everyone an even chance to win some type of award. "

" The object of the game is to win the most tournament prize money (you can use chips) while you roar about some of your own remembered personal misadventures ! "

column19469: "*Star is an abstract strategy connection board game for two players
column19470:
the end product of the evolution from Hex to Y to Poly-Y to Star to *Star." (from website)

Whereas Hex and Y
column19471: the most popular of this line of games
column19473: *Star balances occupying edge spaces and connecting your groups together.  Basically
column19475:
and you lose points for each separate group you have at the end of the game.

The game appears to have a strategic depth similar in style to Go (trying to give groups bases along the edges while also trying to connect groups together in the center; whole-board strategy directing the tactics of each local fight)
column19476: yet with the tactical elegance and simplicity of Hex.  It also retains the mathematical elegance of Hex
column19477: which has nice implications such as the impossibility of draws
column19478:
and the existence of seemingly very different scoring rules which are provably equivalent. Worth a look for fans of Hex and/or Go.
